A specific mutation that is observed with high frequency in a population
Arises due to
- genetic bottleneck (large number of population die)
- selective mating (due to geographical isolation, religious/cultural constraints)
e.g. BRCA mutations in Iceland and Ashkenazi Jews

A specific mutation that is common in a population not due to the founder effect, but due to occuring in lots of different people as an independent event
Commonly in genes with repeditive sequences as this increases mutation rate
e.g. cystic fibrosis CFTR delta 508 mutation
A point mutation in which a single base change results in a codon that codes for a different amino acid compared to the original
Sequence of three nucleotides (bases) that codes for a single protein

Exons are coding areas of DNA - i.e. they code for a protein
Introns are the areas of DNA between the exons, they are removed by RNA splicing before the mature RNA molecule is generated
How many pairs of chromosomes do we normally have?
How many chromosomes do we normally have?
A single point mutation that results in change of codon to a STOP codon (as opposed to a codon that codes for a protein)

An insertion or deletion of one or more nucleotides that shifts the 'reading frame' of a gene
Genes are read in sets of three - three bases make one codon
if a number that is not a multiple of three is added or subtracted, the subsequent bases will be read in different groups of three, altering which amino acid is produced for each
Can result in an early STOP codon and much shorter protein
Tend to produce singificantly abnormal protein (more so than non-frameshift mutations)

e.g.
What is signal to noise ratio, and how is it calculated?

Signal to noise ratio is used to determine the liklihood that detection of a given mutation is of significance
Noise is the frequency of the genetic mutation in the population
Signal is the mutation in cases
The signal-to-noise ratio is calculated by dividing the yield in cases by the background rate of variants of uncertain significance (VUS) in controls.

e.g. long QT signal to noise ratio is 19:1 (for 19 true cases there will be 1 false positive)

What is the difference between Brugada pattern and Brugada syndrome

Describe the mechanism of action of angiotensin receptor-neprilysin inhibitors (ARNI)

Naturetic peptides like BNP promote natriuresis and vasodilation
Neprilysin degrades natriuretic (and other vasoactive) peptides - neprilysin inhibitors block this

Portal hypertension -->
Splanchic arterial vasodilatation (due to increased production of vasodilators, mainly nitric oxide) -->
Decreased effective circulatory volume, rise in cardiac output, fall in systemic vascular resistance -->
RAAS activation -->
Renal vasoconstriction -->
Renal hypoperfusion and hepatorenal syndrome

Type 2: defined as renal impairment that is less severe than that observed with type 1 disease. The major clinical feature is ascites that is resistant to diuretics.

Describe the mechanism of action of calcineurin inhibitors to bring about immunosuppression (2)

Without calcineurin, the nuclear factor of activated T cells (NFAT) does not translocate to the nucleus, and interleukin (IL)-2 production (along with a number of other genes) is shut down
Ultimately T lymphocyte proliferation is reduced
Primarily affects T helper cells
What is the mechanism of action of tacrolimus?

Calcineurin inhibitor
A macrolide antibiotic with immunosuppresive action
Binds to FK-binding proteins, which then competitively binds to and inhibits calcineurin
This inhibits the translocation of a family of transcription factors (NF-AT), leading to reduced transcriptional activation of cytokine genes for
- interleukin (IL)-2
- (TNF)-alpha
- IL-3
- IL-4
- CD40L
- granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor
- interferon-gamma
Ultimately, proliferation of T lymphocytes is reduced.

How is a population of naive B cells with different surface receptors (to match to different antigens) generated from common lymphoid progenitor cells (CLP)?

This results in a unique immunoglobulin displayed on its surface
It can then wait for a matching antigen, and undergo clonal expansion if it does

Describe the difference between avidity and affinity in immunoglobulins

Avidity = overall interaction between antibody and target (how many sites the antigen binds to)
Affinity = strength of interaction between one antibody binding site and its target

A small molecule that alone will not elicit an immune response, but will do so when linked to a larger one (called a carrier)
e.g. penicillin is a tiny molecule, too small to elicit an immune response on its own, but can do so when bound to albumin
What is an adjuvant with regards to immune response?

What screening do B cells undergo just prior to exiting the bone marrow as naive B cells?

What happens to B cells after they exit the bone marrow?

Describe the process of somatic hypermutation of B cells, and how it brings about affinity maturation

Occurs in germinal centres, after a naive B cell has encountered a matching antigen
B cell moves to the germinal centre and multiplies rapidly
Very high mutation rate, random point mutations introduced by AID into the V regions (hypervariable CDR 'hotspots')
Done to try to improve affinity (affinity maturation)
Cells are then tested (at the T cell/B cell border) for increased affinity to the antigen; if higher, they survive, if not, die by apoptosis

Activated B cells, which are proliferating in a germinal centre after being activated by encountering an antigen, switch isotypes (e.g. from IgM/IgD to IgG, IgA, IgE)
They change the constant region of the antibody heavy chain without changing the V regions and thus the specificity to a particular antigen
Changes the effector function of the antibody produced

If their T cell receptor ends up with an interaction with MHC class I -> keep their CD8, get rid of the other
If interacts with MHC class II -> keep their CD4, get rid of the other

What are the role of AIRE and FEZF2 in T cell maturation?

Exists in the cortical epithelial cells of the thymys
Turns on expresiosn of tissue specific Ags at low levels in the thymus
This allows developing T cells to see 'self' from various parts of the body, and be deleted if they react too strongly (deletion of high affinty T cells)

- failure to express tissue-specific antigens in the thymus (for training T cells)
- therefore failyre to delete T cells specific for multiple tissue antigens
autoimmune T cells released into the periphery, causing autoimmunity

Describe T cell activation and co-stimulation

- signal 1: MCH+peptide
- signal 2: co-stimulation

Absence of co-stimulation results in tolerance (no activation)

These interact with CD28 (activation) and CTLA4 (delayed deactivation, eventual cause of switch off of response) on the T cell
Describe the role of IL2 with regards to T cell function

Target in renal cell cancer immunotherapy

A lot of tolerance occurs in the thymus (central tolerance via AIRE)

Peripheral tolerance mediated by
- Inhibitory molecule engagement (CTLA4, PD-1): inhibitory molecules expressed on T cell surface
(this is why checkpoint inhibitors like anti-PD1 results in autoimmunity; lifts the lid on the usual suppressive action of these molecules)
- Angery (MCH and TCR bind but no co-stimulation -> switch off of response or morph to Treg)
- Clonal ignorance: T cells do not 'see' antigen in priviledged sites (brain, eye, testes) as the T cells don't go there, or if they do are killed

How does variation in HLA alleles protect the population from widespread disease?

Some variations in HLA will be good at binding a particular pathogen - it will be readily recognised and prompt an immune response
Other variations in HLA may not bind so well, so the pathogen prompts less response, and the individual is more severely affected
This variation means the population is affected differently by the same pathogen, and we are unlikely to be all wiped out by the same pathogen

Tend to be inherited together in a block (a haplotype)

HLA class II on donor dendritic cells carried with the graft

Describe the indirect pathway leading to chronic organ rejection

Describe how PTH results in increased serum calcium through renal reabsorption

Increases active calcium reabsorption in the distal nephron. 
Activates adenylyl cylclase --> inceases cyclic adenosine monophosphate (AMP) levels --> stimulates protein kinase A --> protein kinase A phosphotylates and activates TRPV5 --> results in increased transceullular calcium transport. Also increases expression of calcium transport proteins TRPV5, calbindin –D28k, NCX1, and PMCA1b.
Describe how PTH is regulated by negative feedback

Elevations in plasma calcium bind to CaSR on parathyroid glands - > lower PTH via negative feedback
Increase in calcitriol inhibits production and secretion of PTH.

99% of renally excreted calcium is reabsorbed
- 70% passively in conjunction with sodium in proximal tubule
- 20% passively in thick ascending loop of Henle via paracellular mechanism mediated by the tight junction protein claudin-16
- 10-15% actively in distal nephron via transcellular mechanism. Calcium enters tubular cells via transient reeptor protential vanilloid 5 (TRPV5) channel, expressed on the apical membrane of both distal convoluted tubule and connecting tubule cells. Inside the cell the calcium binds to calbindin-D28k protein, which takes it to the basolateral surface. It is then extruted into the circulation via two channels, NCX1 and PMCA1b.

Describe the investigations required after finding an incidental adrenal mass

Aldosterone-renin ratio (Conn syndrome)
24hr urine catecholamines +/- plasma metanephrins (Pheochromocytoma)
1mg dexamethasone suppression test (Cushing's)

What investigations should be ordered in suspected Conn's syndrome? (6)

Serum K (low)
Aldosterone (normal or high)
Renin (low)
Aldosterone:renin ratio (high)
Aldosterone suppression test (oral sodium load, measure urine aldosterone) - does not suppress
CT adrenals

Bilateral CT abnormalities
Unliateral abnormality but age > 35

Primary adrenal insufficiency - failure of adrenals to produce cortisol
High ACTH, low cortisol

ACTH stimulation test: cortisol will not rise with ACTH being given (note secondary and tertiary adrenal insufficency also tend not to respond due to atrophy of adrenals)

70-90% autoimmune
Remainder due to infection, malignancy, adrenal haemorrhage/infarction, or drugs
What is the next test that should be ordered in a patient with low testosterone?
FSH, LH (to distinguish primary vs secondary hypogonadism)

24hr urinary free cortisol
Overnight 1mg dexamethasone suppression test

Patient may have Cushing's

ACTH
- if <1, ACTH independent (adrenal source)
- if >65, ACTH dependent (pituitary (most common) or ectopic ACTH cause)
- if 1 - 65, usually ACTH dependent
Consider high dose dexamethasone suppression test
Consider pituitary MRI

BMD may be falsely elevated due to crush fractures making the bone look denser

What would be the expected effect on bone turnover markers (P1NP, CTx) in patients on antiresorptive therapy for osteoporosis?
Which is the 'active' thyroid hormone, T3 or T4?
What is the effect of acute illness on thyroid function?

Non-thyroidal illness syndrome
Result sin low T3
More severe illness results in low T4 and TSH
Treatment is not required
Should exclude pituitary disease if TSH, T3, and T4 all low
Name 3 T cell mediated autoimmune thyroid diseases
Name 3 features of Grave's disease that are relatively specific to the disease (as opposed to the usual signs and symptoms of hyperthyroidism)
Describe the disease course of Graves disease (5)

Relapsing remitting
25% will spontaneously remit
50% will remit with conservative treatment
Once in remission, 25% will recur, 25% will become hypothyroid
Untreated mortality 11 - 50%
What antibody is seen in Graves' disease, and how does it cause disease?

Thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH, thyrotropin)-receptor antibodies (TRAb) 
These activate the receptor, thereby stimulating thyroid hormone synthesis and secretion as well as thyroid growth
Name 3 possible treatments for graves disease

Antithyroid drugs are first line for first time presentations
- Particularly in young patients with small goitre
After 12-18 months and stable on treatment, wean and cease to see if remission has occured
Describe the initial management of Graves' disease in patients with large goitres with obstructive symptoms

Commence antithryoid drugs to achieve euthyroidism
Then surgery
If not fit for surgery, radioactive iodine may be used instead
Describe the management of recurrent or severe Graves' disease

Antithyroid treatment until euthyroid
Then either radioactive iodine or surgery
Describe the management of Graves' disease in older patients
What is the antithyroid drug of choice in Graves' disease?
Describe the management of Graves' disease in pregnancy (5)

Propylthiouracil before conception and in first trimester
Then switch to carbimazole
If hyperthyroidism is difficult to control after the first trimester, requiring high carbimazole dose, consider surgery
Be aware high risk of postpartum recurrence
Block-replace therapy is contraindicated in pregnancy

Radioactive iodine should NOT be used in moderate or severe orbitopathy

Describe the symptomatic management of Graves' disease

Rash (10%)
Foetal abnormalities in 1st trimester
Agranulocytosis (0.4%) - sudden, acute, and idiosyncratic (no monitoring)
- Patients should stop drug if coryza or unexplained fever
Mild neutropenia

bHCG is similar to TSH, has TSH activity
Causes a mild hyperthyroidism that self-resolves as bHCG drops after the 1st trimester
Usually no teatment required
Describe the investigation findings in Graves' disease (2)

Low TSH, high T3, normal T4
Radioiodine scan: diffuse increased uptake

Result of focal and/or diffuse hyperplasia of thyroid follicular cells whose functional capacity is independent of regulation by TSH
Women > men
Onset age > 50
Nodular goitre often present for years
Hyperthyroidism may be after iodine load e.g. contrast

T3 > T4
Thyroid uptake scan: normal or multifocal uptake

Radioactive iodine is first line

Somatic activating mutation of TSH receptor gene or of signal transduction gene (G protein gene)
Female > male
Onset age 30 - 50
Slow growing solitary nodule, usually >3cm
Describe the management of toxic thyroid adenoma

Radioactive iodine is first line
Remission is rare without definitive treatment.
Describe the investigation results in toxic thyroid adenoma (2)

T3 > T4
Radionuclide scan: focal uptake with suppression of surrounding thyroid uptake
Describe the difference between T3 and T4 hyperthyroidism

T3 toxicosis: high T3, normal T4. Seen in Graves' and toxic multinodular goitre.
T4 toxicosis: high T4, normal T3. Seen in nonthyroidal illnesss that decreases extrathyroidal conversion of T4 to T3, and in amiodarone-induced hyperthyroidism
Name 3 risk factors for gestational thyrotoxicosis

Anything that is associated with higher bHCG, such as
- twin pregnancy
- molar pregnancy
- hyperemesis gravidarum

High TSH, high T3 and T4
Very rare
Due to TSH secreting pituitary adenoma or partial resistance to feedback from T3/T4

Low TSH, normal or high T4 and/or T3 (levothyroxine is T4)
Low serum thyroglobulin

A teratoma of thyroid tissue
5% of ovarian teratomas
A rare differential for women with hyperthyroidism without goitre who have minimal/absent uptake on radioiodine scan (this is usually due to exogenous thyroxine intake or thyroiditis)

Both will have low TSH, high T3 and/or T4, no goitre, and low/absent neck radioiodine uptake
- exogenous use will have low thyroglobulin
- struma ovarii will have normal thyroglobulin

Low TSH, disproportionately high T4 compared to T3
Thyroglobulin and IL-6 may be elevated in type 2 (but overlap)
Radioiodine scan: low uptake
Ultrasound: normal or increased vascularity in type 1, diminished or absent in type 2

Type 1: increased thyroid hormone synthesis due to iodine load
Type 2: destructive thyroiditis
Describe the management of amiodarone induced thyrotoxicosis type 1

Antithyroid drugs (carbimazole)
Stop amiodarone unless life-threatening indication

If normal TSH with high T4, no treatment
Describe the management of amiodarone induced thyrotoxicosis type 2

Prednisolone 40 - 50mg daily
Stop amiodarone unless life-threatening indication

If high T4 but normal TSH, no treatment required
In many patients with amiodarone induced hyperthyroidism, differentiating between type 1 and 2 can be difficult. Describe the management approach in this group.

Carbimazole and prednisolone
If rapid response (50% T4 fall in 2 weeks), is type 2 - stop carbimazole, continue prednisolone. Otherwise, do the reverse.
Stop amiodarone unless life-threatening indication
Surgery if deteriorates despite therapy
Describe the management of subclinical hyperthyroidism

If TSH < 0.1 and persists, treat.
- antithyroids if subclinical Graves' and young
- radioiodine for older patient with multinodular goitre

Yes - progression to overt disease, osteoporosis, atrial fibrillation, heart failure.
Describe 6 clinical features of thyroid storm

Fever
Tachycardia/arrythmia (e.g. rapid AF)
Proximal myopathy and tremor
Nausea, abdo pain, jaundice
Dehydration, shock
Coma/seizure/delirium
End organ dysfunction - often hepatic
Name 5 factors which may precipitate thyroid storm

Infection
Trauma
Surgery (especially thyroid)
Radioiodine (rare)
Poor compliance with antithyroid drugs

May or may not have a history of thyrotoxicosis

HDU or ICU

Propylthiouracil (PO or rectal) to block synthesis, AND
Lugol solution to block hormone release
Consider adding dexamethasone
Consider adding cholestyramine (to increase T4 clearance)

Control tachycardia with:
propranolol or esmolol

Plasmapheresis if desparate
Plan for thyroidectomy when stable

Raised TSH (<10) and normal T3/T4
2.6% progress to hypothyroidism per year
Do not treat if TSH < 10, unless pregnant or planning pregnancy (in which case treat TSH > 4)
Check antibodies to predict progression

Severe hypothyroidism leading to slowing of function in multiple organs
It is a medical emergency with a high mortality rate (40%)
Hallmarks: decreased mental status, hypothermia. 
Often with hypotension, bradycardia, hyponatraemia, hypoglycaemia, hypoventilation
Describe the treatment of myxedema coma (3)

Thyroid hormone (T4/levothyroxine and T3/liothyronine) IV
High dose glucocorticoids
ICU and supportive measures

Probably a post-viral syndrome, often follows URTI
Destruction of thyroid follicles and release of stored thyroid hormone
HLAB35 positive in 75%
Female: male 5:1

Describe the clinical presentation of subacute thyroiditis

Neck pain, radiating up to the jaw
Tender diffuse goitre
Hyperthyroidism for 1-2 months, then hypothyroidism for 4 - 6 months (permanent hypothryoid in 10%)

Low TSH < 0.1, raised T3/T4
Low uptake on radiodine uptake scan
High ESR, CRP
Describe the management of subacute thyroiditis (4)

NSAID or aspirin for pain relief
Prednisolone 40mg/day if no relief with above, or if severe pain
Beta blockers if troublesome hyperthyroid symptoms
Thyroxine replacement in hypothyroid phase if symptomatic

No role for antithyroid drugs or radioactive iodine (thyroiditis results in release of preformed hormone)

Autoimmune process, destruction of thyroid follicles with release of preformed hormone
Incidence 2-5%
1 - 6 months after delivery
More common in type 1 diabetics, patients with positive antithyroid peroxxidase antibodies, and who have had it before
Describe the clinical findings in postpartum thyroiditis (3)

Diffuse, small goitre
Painless
Classic pattern: hyperthyroid for 1-2 months, followed by hypothyroid for 4 - 6 months; hypothyroid permanent in 20%

Describe the investigation results in postpartum thyroiditis (4)

Hyperthyroid pattern if hyperthyroid phase, hypothyroid pattern in hypothyroid phase
Radionuclide thyroid scan: near absent uptake
TPO antibody high tire positive, anti-Tg positive
Normal ESR

Describe the management of postpartum thyroiditis (2)

Betablocker if symptomatic of hyperthyroidism (propranolol preferred)
Thyroxine in hypothyroid phase if symptomatic, breastfeeding, or trying to conceive
Gradual thyroid failure, with or without goitre, due to autoimmune-mediated destruction of the thyroid gland and apoptosis of thyroid epithelial cells
Describe the biopsy findings in Hashimoto's thyroiditis
Name 2 autoantibodies one would expect to be positive in Hashimoto's thyroiditis
Describe the usual clinical course in Hashimoto's thyroiditis
In patients with Hashimoto's thyroiditis, is hypothyroidism typically permanent or transient?
Describe the pathogenesis of Hashimoto's thyroiditis (6)

Starting point is not known - may be molecular mimicry or bystander activation

Once started:
B cells secrete anti-thyroid antibodies
T cells react with processed thyroid antigens, then secrete cytokines to activate other immune cells
- Th2 get involved with antibody production
- Th1 cytotoxic T cells cause apoptotic destruction of thyroid cells
- T cells regulate the local immune response
Describe the concept of molecular mimicry

Foreign antigen shares similar structure to 'self' substance
Anti-foreign response cross-reacts with self
e.g. rheumatic fever and streptococcal infection, reactive arthritis, narcolepsy after H1N1 fluvax
Describe the concept of bystander activation with regards to immunology

Anti-self T cells usually tolerised by presentation of self-antigen by immature tolerogenic dendritic cells (that do not express B7 so cannot co-stimulate and produce a response)
Infection engages innate immunoreceptors and stimulates B7 expression
--> activation of self-reactive T cells
What is the most common cause of hypothyroidism in iodine-sufficient areas?
Name the 2 forms of Hashimoto's thyroiditis, and how they differ

Goitrous
Atrophic

Different degree of lymphocytic infiltration, fibrosis, and thyroid follicuylar cell hyperplasia
Same pathophysiology
At what rate do patients with subclinical hypothyroidism and thyroid antibodies progress to overt hypothyroidism?
Name 4 risk factors for Hashimoto's thyroiditis

Female
Age
Personal or family history of autoimmune phenomena (e.g. type 1 diabetes)
High iodine intake

Thought to be due to autoimmune vasculitis, not due to thyroid disease
Heterogenous presentation - fulminant, subacute, or chronic course of declining mental status, with seizures and myoclonus
Positive anti-TPO, other findings nonspecific
Manage with trial of corticosteroid
Majority have good outcome

A varient of Hashimoto's thyroiditis
Autoimmune destructoin of thyroid follicles, release of preformed thyroid hormone
Female > male
Age 20 - 50
Nonpainful, diffuse small goiter
Hyperthyroidism 1-2 months, followed by hypothyroid 4- 6 months, then recovery (permanent hypothyroid 20%)

Betablocker if hyperthryoid symptoms

What percentage of 'hot' thyroid nodules are malignant?

Name 7 features suggestive of malignancy on thyroid nodule ultrasound

TI-RADS score

Three points:
Very hypoechoic
Taller-than-wide
Extrathyroid extension
Punctate echogenic foci

Two points:
Solid (rather than cystic or mixed)

<1cm: repeat evaluation in 6 - 12 months

Mutations in the mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) pathway

What 2nd agent should be chosen for blood pressure control in patients with diabetes?

Discrepency between uptodate and college lecture

- college lecture recommends DHP calcium channel blocker (e.g. amlodipine) and states this is superior to diuretic (hydrochlorothiazide)

At least one of them should be taken in the evening - reduces cardiovascular event rate

Reduce saturated fat, trans fat, cholesterol intake

Weight loss
Exercise, break up sedentary time

All of them, regardless of lipid profile

Ezetimibe
Reduces risk of cardiovascular events, in addition to statin (primary prevention)

At least < 130

No, not routinely

In diabetic patients with known cardiovascular disease, what medications should be used to prevent events? (4)

ACE inhibitor
Statin
Aspirin
If prior myocardial infarction: beta blocker for at least 2 years
Describe the actions of glucacon-like peptide 1 (GLP1) (5)

GLP1 is an incretin
Produced from the proglucagon gene in L-cells of the small intestine and is secreted in response to nutrients
Binds to GLP-1 receptor in various tissues, including pancreatic beta cells, stimulating glucose-dependent insulin release
Also slows gastric emptying, inhibits glucacon, reduces food intake
Degraded by dipeptidyl peptidase-4 (DPP-4)

Inhibit DPP4, which breaks down glucagon like peptide 1 (GLP1) and gastric inhibitory polypeptide (GIP)

Do DPP4 inhibitors (gliptins) improve cardiovascular outcomes in type 2 diabetes, in addition to conventional glucose-lowering therapy?
Do SGLT2 inhibitors improve cardiovascular outcomes in type 2 diabetes, in addition to conventional blood glucose control?

Yes - EMPA-REG study
14% lower CV death, nonfatal MI, or nonfatal stroke
32% lower mortality
35% less hospitalisaion for heart failure

40% reduction in renal complications as well in a similar trial
Do GLP1 agonists improve cardiovascular outcomes in type 2 diabetes, in addition to conventional blood glucose control?
Name 2 glucose-lowering medications that, in addition to standard blood sugar control, improve cardiovascular outcomes in type 2 diabetes

SGLT2 inhibitors (e.g. empagliflozin) (also improve renal outcomes)
GLP1 agonists (e.g. exenatide)
What is the best indicator of chronic kidney disease in diabetes?

eGFR

Does tight glycaemic control in type 2 diabetes improve renal outcomes?
Which patients with type 1 or 2 diabetes should be on ACE or ARB to prevent renal disease/prevent progression of renal disease?

Patients with hypertension and any degree of albuminuria (including macroalbuminuria)

Yearly eGFR/creatinine, urinary albumin excretion, potassium
Name 9 interventions in diabetes that improve outcomes in terms of primary prevention of complications

Lifestyle modifications, smoking cessation
Intensive BSL control, aim HbA1c < 6.5
ACE if hypertensive (to prevent CVS disease)
ACE if hypertension and any degree of albuminuria (to prevent renal disease)
Statin for all patients (unless age < 40 and no risk factors)
- Add ezetimibe if inadequate control on statin
- Add fenofibrate if high triglycerides and low HDL
SGLT2 inhibitor
GLP1 agonist
Dunedin lecture wants us to consider aspirin for primary cardiovascular disease prevention  if 10 year CVD risk >10% and no increased bleeding risk, and also for primary stroke prevention
Does intensive multifactorial intervention in diabetes (ACE, statin, intensive BSL control, lifestyle, etc) improve outcomes in diabetes?
Yes, improvement in complications and mortality
What is the effect of ACE inhibitors on the afferent and efferent arterioles of the glomerulus?
What medication is derived from this guy?

This is a Gila monster!

What is the mechanism of action of sulfonylureas?
Increase insulin secretion via the pancreatic sulfonylurea receptor
Give the equation for calculating incidence from carrier frequency for autosomal recessive disorders

Incidence = 4 x (carrier frequency)2

Example:
Friedreich ataxia has carrier frequency of 1/100
100 squared = 10,000
10,000 x4 = 40,000
Incidence is 1 in 40,000
Give the equation for calculating carrier frequency from incidence for autosomal recessive disorders

Carrier frequency = square root of (Incidence/4)

Example
The incidence of cystic fibrosis = 1 in 2,500 Caucasians
2500/4 = 625
Square root of 625 = 25
Carrier frequency = 1 in 25
What is the Hardy-Weinberg equation? Give an example on how to use it for cystic fibrosis.

p²+ 2pq+ q² = 1
Where:
p is the indicence of allele 1
q is the incidence of allele 2
2pq is the frequency of the carrier state

Example:
Let q be the gene for cystic fibrosis, and p be the normal gene

For CF the frequency of qq in northern Europeans = 1 in 2500

     q2=1/2500

     q = 1/50
     
     Since the sum of the alleles   q + p = 1 , p = 1 - q

     p= 49/50

     Carrier frequency = 2pq= 2*(49/50)(1/50) = 98/2500 =.04

Secreted by the posterior pituitary
Results in V2 receptor mediated aquaporin insertion 
Aquaporin in distal convoluted tubule
Increased free water reabsorption, concentrated urine, lower serum sodium (due to water reabsoprtion)

osmolar gap = osmolality (measured) - osmolality (calculated)

>10 is abnormal and indicates presence of extra osmotically active particles (i.e. other than sodium, glucose, and urea)
e.g. glycine post TURP, mannitol post IVIG
What are the 4 most common causes of severe hyponatraemia (<120)?
Patients with hyponatraemia should not be rapidly corrected to avoid what complication?

Osmotic demyelination syndrome
- occurs if there is rapid correction and the hyponatraemia had been present >2 days, as the brain has adapted to the hypotonicity
- higher risk at lower Na levels
How quickly can hyponatraemia be corrected, keeping in mind risk of osmotic demyelination syndrome?

Aim to correct by 4-6mmol/L per 24hrs
Maximum is 10mmol per 24hrs
Only correct more rapidly if definitely known to be <48hrs since onset
Name 15 drugs that can cause hyponatraemia
How do thiazides result in hyponatraemia? (3)

Sodium and potassium loss
Stimulation of thirst
Impaired urinary dilution
Name 5 drugs or drug classes that cause hyponatraemia by stimulated ADH release
Name 2 drugs or drug classes that cause hyponatreaemia by potentiating the action of ADH in the kidneys

Glucose
Lipids
Cortisol

Urine Na and K

A type of hypertonic hyponatraemia
Omolality typically > 290
High blood sugar causes water to move out of cells via osmosis, expanding extracellular fluid volume -> dilutional hyponatraemia
Describe how sodium level can be corrected for hyperglycaemia

Decrease sodium by 2mmol/L for every 5.5mmol/L increase in BSL

Simple version: divide BSL by 3 and add to sodium

e.g. Na = 120, BSL = 60
120 + 20

Most causes of hyponatraemia are hypotonic, isotonic, or hypertonic?

GI losses
Excessive sweating

Diuretics (thiazides)
Salt-losing nephropathy
Cerebral salt wasting syndrome

Low urine sodium as they try to retain it to increase circulating volume

e.g.
Heart failure
Cirrhosis
Nephrotic syndrome

Name 2 causes of hypotonic hypervolaemic hyponatraemia with high urinary sodium (>20)
Describe the management of hypotonic hypervolaemic hyponatraemia

Treat underlying cause (e.g. heart failure, cirrhosis)
Fluid restrict
+/- diuresis
+/- conc albumin (if cirrhosis)

Renin is synthesised in juxtaglomerular cells
Secreted in response to renal hypoperfusion
Renin cleaves angiotensin I from angiotensinogen
ACE catalyses conversion of angiotensin I to angiotensin II (mostly in the lung)
Angiotensin II causes arteriolar vasoconstriction and sodium reabsorption by the kidney
Aldosterone is secreted from the adrenal cortex in response to angiotensin II
Aldosterone binds to mineralocorticoid receptors, causing salt and water retention and potassium secretion

Secreted by the adrenal cortex in response to angiotensin II
Binds to minteralocorticoid receptors
--> increases the expression of epithelial sodium channels in the distal tubule, causing salt and water retention, potassium wasting

Occurs in chronic low effective arterial blood volume states, e.g. CCF, cirrhosis, CKD
Instead of normal attenuation of effect of aldosterone (salt/water retaning, potassium wasting), the effect continues

Water intoxication (psychogenic, NMDA use, marathons)

SIADH
Nonosmotic physiological ADH release (stress, pain, nausea)

SIADH is a diagnosis of exclusion where:

Euvolaemic
Low serum osmolality < 275

Drugs (e.g. carbamazepine, cyclophosphamide)
Surgery
Pulmonary disease (e.g. pneumonia, asthma, atelectasis, acute respiratory failure, pneumothorax)
Hypopituitarism and hypothyroidism
Hormone administration (oxytocin, vasopressin)
HIV
Hereditary
Idiopathic

Describe the life cycle of HIV (7)

Binding: binds to CD4 and one of to co-receptors, CXCR4 or CCR5
Fusion: fuses with the host cell and release RNA into it
Reverse transcription: single stranded RNA is converted to HIV DNA by reverse transcriptase
Integration: HIV DNA enters the nucleus, integrase (an enzyme) cuts the cell's DNA and inserts HIV DNA
Transcription and translation: RNA polymerase makes RNA copies of DNA. HIV RNA is inserted into new virus particles or processed and translated into HIV proteins.
Assembly: gag molecules, viral RNA, and envelope proteins are packaged into the growing virus that buds off from the host cell
Release and maturation: viral protease cleaves the gag molecules into individual functional proteins. Mature virus can now infect other cells.

in immunodeficiency:

Where does the spinal cord end?
Can lumbar level pathology give upper motor neuron signs?
Describe the path of the corticospinal tract

Contain upper motor neurones that original at M1 of the primary motor cortex in the posterior frontal lobe
Fibres run to the internal capsule, become more closely packed
Go down through the brainstem
Decussate at the lower medulla (80 - 85% of fibres decussate and become the lateral corticospinal tract; the remainder do not and are the anterior corticospinal tract)
Synapse on the anterior horn cells

Lateral corticospinal tract contains majority of fibres (80 - 85%)
The dorsal columns control what sensory modalities (2)
Describe the path of the dorsal columns

Input from large sensory fibres in peripheral nerve
Enter through the dorsal horn, into the dorsal column ipsilaterally
Decussate at the cervicomedullary junction
Up to the thalamus and into the sensory cortex
The anterior and lateral spinothalamic tracts carry what three sensory modalities?
Describe the path of the spinothalamic tract

Input from small sensory fibres in peripheral nerves
Enter through the dorsal root ganglion
Decussate almost immediately (within 1-2 segments)
Terminate in the thalamus (and a little to the cortex)
Name the 3 major white matter tracts of clinical importance

Corticospinal tract
Dorsal colum
Anterior and lateral spinothalamic tracts
This is an example of an intramedullary, intradural, or extradural mass of the spinal cord?
Intramedullary (i.e. mass is whithin the spinal cord itself)
This is an example of an intramedullary, intradural, or extradural mass of the spinal cord?

Extradural mass
This is a mass from outside the spinal cord that is pushing on it
This is an example of an intramedullary, intradural, or extradural mass of the spinal cord?
Intradural mass, e.g. fibroma or meningioma
What is 'lamination' of the spinal cord and how is it clincally relevent?

The lateral tracts (lateral corticospinal tract, lateral spinothalamic tract) have their fibres ordered laterally to medially from lowest (sacral) to highest (cervical)
This means extrinsic compression will affect the lower levels more, have a vague upper limit of the sensory level
Intrinsic compression will affect the upper levels more, have a crisp upper limit of involvement and attenuated lower level involvement with sacral sparing
What is the classic cause of a 'central cord pattern' of involvement?
Syringomyelia - fluid-filled, gliosis-lined cavity within the spinal cord
Describe the pattern of involvement in syringomyelia

Central spinal cord lesion
Involves decussating fibres of the spinothalamic tract (so they lesion will cause sensory loss at and above the level of the lesion)
- sensory loss of only pain and temperature
- sparing of dorsal column (joint position, vibration)
May have direct involvement of the anterior horn cells causing lower motor involvement
Finger jerk reflex corresponds to what level?
Triceps jerk reflex corresponds to what level?

Also called hemi-cord syndrome
Unilateral involvement of the dorsal column, corticospinal tract, and spinothalamic tract
Weakness, loss of vibration, and loss of proprioception on ipsilateral side below the level of the lesion
Loss of pain and temperature on the opposite side below the level of the lesion (the spinothalamic tract, because it decussates almost immediately)

Causes include knife/bullet wounds, demyelination.
Most spinal cord blood supply within the cord is provided by?

Anterior spinal artery
However the posterior columns (including the dorsal column) are supplied by the posterior spinal arteries)
What clincal picture would you expect with occlusion of the anterior spinal artery?

Dense paraplegia involving motor (corticospinal) and spinothalamic tracts, as these are supplied by the anterior spinal artery
May spare the posterior columns (including the dorsal column), as supply is by the posterior spinal arteries
Describe subactue combined degeneration of the cord

Caused by pernicious anaemia with B12 deficiency
 - Similar picture rarely caused by copper deficiency, viamint E deficiency, nitrous oxide intoxication
Degeneration of dorsal and lateral white matter (dorsal column, corticospinal tract)
Results in slowly progressive weakness, sensory ataxia, and paraesthesia
Ultimately results in spasticity, paraplegia, incontinence
Not all patients have anaemia or macrocytosis
B12 supplementation halts or reverses progression

Bilateral, not not necessarily symmetric, sensorimotor and autonomic spinal cord dysfunction
Clearly defined sensory level
Progression to nadir of deficits between 4hrs and 21 days from onset
Demonstraction of spinal cord inflammation (CSF pleocytosis or elevated IgG indec, or MRI shows gadolinium enhancing cord lesion)
Exclusion of compressive, post-RT, neoplastic, vascular causes

Segmental spinal cord injury caused by acute inflammation
Usually idiopathic, presumed autoimmune
50% have preceding infection

Can be part of the presentatin of neuromyelitis optica
Associated with connective tissue disease

Inflammation in 1-2 spinal cord segments, usually in the thoraic cord

MRI: Gadolinium-enhancing signal abnormality, usually extending over one or more cord segments. The cord often appears swollen at these levels. 
CSF: abnormal in 50%; elevated protein (usually 100 to 120 mg/100 mL) and moderate lymphocytosis (usually <100/mm3). Glucose levels are normal. Oligoclonal bands are usually not present in isolated TM, and when present suggest a higher risk of subsequent MS

- Chronic denervation and reinnervation findings: large-amplitude, long-duration, complex motor unit action potentials (MUAPs) with neurogenic recruitment and a reduced interference pattern.

Fasciculation potentials may also appear in denervated muscle and represent spontaneous firing of motor units that are not voluntarily recruited. Fasciculations may be visible to the naked eye when they occur on the surface of muscles

PLUS
rifampicin

ethambutol

pyrazinamide

Describe the management of TB therapy induced hepatitis

If ALT 2 - 5x ULN and asymptomatic - monitor
If >5x ULN or symptoms, cease all therapy
- if can't interrupt, use ethambutol, moxiflocacin, amikacin
Restart once ALT < 2x ULT
- restart ethambutol + rifampicin, then isoniazid. If tolerated, it was probably the pyrazinamide; do not restart this, and extend therapy to 9 months instead.
What is primary drug resistance in TB?

What is secondary drug resistance in TB?

Why do we use combination therapy in TB?

Large number of TB bacteria (109 - 1010 bacteria), because of this at least a few will be resistant to any given drug due to spontaneous mutation
- isoniazid, 1 in 106
- rifampicin, 1 in 108
However chance of spontaneous mutation to more than one drug is highly unlikely
Use multiple drugs to kill off the resistant clones (may be resistant to one drug, but will not be to the other)
Describe the treatment of isoniazid-resistant TB
Describe the treatment of pyrazinamide resistant TB

Resistance to isoniazid and rifampicin (+/- other resistance)
1.7% of Australian cases

Resistance to rifapicin AND isoniazid AND quinolones AND at least one injectable (amikacin, kanamycin, or capreomycin)
Morality >20%
Name 2 risk factors for multi drug resistant TB

Previous TB treatment
- 60 - 70% have no history of prior treatment
Contact with multi drug resistant TB or residence in a 'hot zone'
Describe how testing for multi drug resistant TB is performed

Rapid drug resistance detection: genotypic detection of rifampicin by analysis of rifampicin resistance determining region, rpoB, via PCR (GeneXpert)
- Can detect TB, and also if resistant
- Sensitivity 98% if smear positive, 75% if smear negative (improve to 90% with 3 sputums)
Rifampicin resistance is highly predictive of multi-drug resistant TB
What is the test of choice for rapid diagnosis of TB in HIV positive patients?

GeneXpert (cartridge-based PCR for rpoB)
30% more sensitive than smear in HIV
Describe the Bangladeshi regimen management of multi drug resistant TB

4 months: Isoniazid (double dose) + moxifloxacin + pyrazinamide + ethambutol + amikacin + prothionamide + clofazimine
5 - 8 months: pyrazinamide, ethambutol, moxiflocaxin

Success 80 - 90%
Cannot use in pregnancy, extrapulmonary TB
Describe treatment of multi drug resistant TB

Aim for 5 drugs, at least 12 months treatment

An injectable (amikacin or capreomycin)
A fluoroquinolone (moxiflocacin)
Two drugs from group C (linezolid, clofazimine)
Then one from group D1, D2, or D3

Consider surgical resection in selected cases

Cavitation rare

Smear negative more common
Extrapulmonary more common (40 - 80%)
- nodes

- meningitis
- dissemination, bacteraemia

Do not use
Tenofovir alafenamide + rifampicin (old tenofovir, tenofovir disoproxil is OK)

AND

Name 4 mechanisms by which microbes can acquire antibiotic resistance

Antibiotic inactivation, e.g. beta lactamases
Alterationo fo antibiotic target site
Decreased antibiotic permeability of the cell wall, preventing drug access to target
Active antibiotic efflux from the bacteria

Secreted by gram positive organisms, into the milieu surrounding the organism (they are exoenzymes)
Confer resistance to beta lactam antibiotics

Also found in the periplasmic space in gram negative pathogens
Describe the appearance of staph aureus
Gram positive cocci in grape-like bunches (not chains)
This is a CSF sample. What is the abnormality?

Large number of white blood cells
Inside the neutrophil in the centre are gram negative diplococci - neisseria meningitidis (meningococcal meningitis)

It is a beta lactam
Acts as a 'suicide inhibitor' of beta lactamases - binds to beta lactamase and prevents it from inactivating the antibiotic it is co-administered with (typically amoxicillin), to overcome beta lactamase penicillin resistance

Organisms with inducible chromosomally-mediated beta lactamase production
Will appear sensitive to beta lactams on initial testing, but quickly become resistant with therapy
Beta lactam antibiotics should never be used.

Serratia
Citrobacter
ACinetobacter

PBPs are associate with the bacterial cell membrane

- e.g. penicillin resistant strep pneumoniae

mecA gene

Direct inhibitors of bacterial DNA synthesis - target bacterial enzymes DNA gyrase and topoisomerase IV
Bactericidal
e.g. moxifloxacin, ciprofloxacin

Alteration of the target, bacterial DNA gyrase

Inhibit bacterial DNA-dependent RNA polymerase, as a result of drug binding in the polymerase subunit deep within the DNA/RNA channel, facilitating direct blocking of the elongating RNA 
E.g. rifampicin

Gram negative bacteria have porins in their cell wall, through which antibiotics enter
Changes in the size and hydrophobicity of these can decrease penetration by antibiotics
e.g. resistance in enterobacteriaceae and pseudomonas to trimethoprim and fluoroquinolones

Where 0 is no angina, 1 is non-limiting angina and 2 is exercise limiting angina.

The modified Bruce protocol adds two low-workload stages to the beginning of the standard Bruce protocol.

150mL

The normal volume of air displaced between normal inhalation and exhalation when extra effort is not applied.

The maximum volume of air that can be expelled following maximum inhalation.

The volume of air remaining in the lungs after a maximal exhalation.

The volume of gas in the lung after a normal expiration.
Describe the forumula for calculating the alveolar-arterial gradient (A-a gradient).

PAO2 - PaO2

PaO2 is obtained through an arterial blood gas
PAO2 = FiO2(Patm - PH20) - (PaCO2/0.8)
Name the most common cause of carbon monoxide poisoning.

Congenital (due to reduced enzymatic reduction of methaemoglobin back to functional haemoglobin)
Acquired (typically due to ingestion of specific drugs that increase production of methaemoglobin)
An altered state of haemoglobin in which the ferrous (Fe++) irons of heme are oxidzed to the ferric (Fe+++) state.

The ferric hemes of methaemoglobin are unable to reversibly bind oxygen. In addition, the oxygen affinity of any remaining globins' ferrous hemes in the haemoglobin tetramer are increased. Results in the oxygen dissociation curve being "left-shifted" (i.e. haemoglobin has higher affinity for oxygen and there is less delivery of oxygen to the tissues). Thus, patients with methaemoglobinaemia have a functional anaemia and may develop a compensatory polycythemia.
Describe the 2 pathways for reduction of methaemoglobinaemia back to haemoglobin.

NADH-dependent reaction catalyzed by cytochrome b5 reductase.
NADPH generated by glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD). This pathway is not normally physiologically active, but drugs can activate this pathway in order to facilitate treatment of methamoglobinaemia.
Name 2 drugs which commonly cause methaemoglobinaemia.

Dapsone
Topical anaesthetics (benzacaine, lignocaine, prilocaine)

Describe the physiological action of proprotein convertase subtilsin kexin 9 (PCSK9).

PCSK9 is a serine protease secreted by the liver. It binds the LDLR expressed principally on liver cells. Once the PCSK9-LDLR complex is internalized into the hepatocyte through the coated pit region of its outer membrane, LDL receptors bound to PCSK9 are prevented from recycyling to the cell surface and undergo destruction inside liver cells. Fewer LDL receptors lead to less clearance of LDL-C and higher serum levels.
White or grey ring around the cornea which is due to an abnormal deposit of cholesterol in the eyes.
Name the 2 most common locations for tendon xanthomata in familial hypercholesterolaemia.
Describe the fasting lipid profile seen in patients with familial hypercholesterolaemia.

Elevated total cholesterol
Elevated low density lipoprotein cholesterol
Normal or low high-density lipoprotein cholesterol
Normal triglyceride levels (unless the patient is obese, has diabetes, or other mutations in triglyceride-regulating genes)
Give a definition for paroxysmal atrial fibrillation.
Atrial fibrillation which is intermittent and self-terminating without intervention within 7 days of onset.
Give a definition for persistent atrial fibrillation.
Atrial fibrillation which fails to terminate within 7 days of onset.

Ongoing monitoring with serial endoscopies for evaluate for disease response, recurrence and development of gastric adenocarcinoma.

If intra-abdo distant nodes or distant disease, need more intensive treatment

Extranodal marginal zone lymphoma of mucosa associated lymphoid tissue (MALT lymphoma)

A type of non-Hodgkin lymphoma that appears to arise from post-germinal center marginal zone B cells.

These tumours are unlikely to respond to Helicobacter Pylori eradication therapy. Still recommended to attempt H. Pylori eradication therapy in the first instance.
Name the most effective antiarrhythmic agent for suppressing ventricular tachycardia.
In patients who have had a recent myocardial infarction, which class of antiarrhythmic drugs increase the risk of sudden cardiac death?

Among patients with recent myocardial infarction and increased ventricular ectopy, do antiarrhythmic agents improve survival?

Among patients with recent myocardial infarction and increased ventricular ectopy, use of antiarrythmics suppresses ventricular ectopy, but increases mortality.
Name the protein to which CRP binds which helps facilitate recognition of foreign pathogens and the phospholipid constituents of damaged cells.
ESR is an indirect acute phase reactant which reflects plasma viscosity. It is particularly influenced by what protein?
What is the effect of anaemia on the erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR)?

Anaemia increases the sedimentation rate (high ESR). ESR is measured in mm/hour.
The sedimentation of red blood cells is presumably impeded by other red blood cells; sedimentation is thus more rapid in anaemia, in which this retardation is lessened.
What is the effect of obesity on erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) and C-reactive protein (CRP)?
ESR and CRP can be elevated in obesity; this is due at least in part to inerleukin (IL)-6 secretion by adipose tissu.
What is the effect of renal impairment on erythrocyte sedimentation rate?

ESR is elevated in almost all patients with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) or the nephrotic syndrome and is unaffected by haemodialysis. Nearly 60% of patients with ESRD have an ESR > 60mm/hour, while 20% have extreme elevations > 100 mm/hour. The presence of an isolated ESR elevation in these patients without other signs or symtpoms, does not indicate the presence of infection, disease activity or an underlying malignancy.
Name the most common cause of death due to native valve infective endocarditis.

Heart failure is usually due to valvular insufficiency from infection-induced valvular damage. Disease affecting the aortic valve and infection with Staphylococcus aureus increases the likelihood of heart failure.
Name 2 factors which increase the likelihood of a patient with native valve infective endocarditis developing heart failure.

Involvement of aortic valve
Infection with Staphylococcus aureus
Name the most common reason patients with native valve infective endocarditis require cardiac surgery.
Name 4 indications for early surgery in native valve infective endocarditis.

Signs or symptoms of heart failure (due to valve insufficiency)
Paravalvular extension with annular/aortic abscess, penetrating lesion and/or heart block
Difficult to treat organism (fungal or multiresistant bacteria)
Persistent fever or bacteraemia despite 7 days of antibiotcs
Early surgery is surgery that is performed before completion of a full course of antibiotics.
Give a definition for ESR (erythrocyte sedimentation rate).
Rate at which erythrocytes suspended in plasma settle when placed in a vertical tube (measured in mm/hour).
ESR is an indirect acute phase reactant whih reflects plasma viscosity and the presence of acute phase proteins, especially fibrinogen.
Give a definition for an acute phase reactant.
A protein whose serum concentration increases or decreases by at least 25% during inflammatory states.
What is the effect of age on the erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR)?
Age markedly increases the sedimentation rate.
Changes in acute phase reactants reflect altered production by hepatocytes in response to primarily which cytokine?
Name the preferred antibiotic choice for patients with methicillin-susceptible Staphyloccocal infective endocarditis.
For methicillin-susceptible staphylococci use flucloxacillin 2g, IV, 4-hourly, for 4 - 6 weeks.
4 weeks may be adequate for uncomplicated cases; 6 weeks should be given if there are complications (perivalvular abscess, septic metastatic complications)
Patients with what complication of native valve infective endocarditis do best with surgical intervention?
Surgery should be undertaken as soon as signs/symptoms of heart failure appear, before haemodynamic instability develops.

Mildly elevated low density and very low density lipoprotein (LDL and VLDL)

Patients in the early stages of primary biliary cholangitis often have mild elevations of low-density and very-low-density lipoproteins and striking elevations of high-density lipoproteins (HDL). HDL levels tend to decrease in the later stages of the disease, while triglyceride levels are often elevated.

ALP 1.5 times the upper limit of normal
Presence of AMA antibodies 1:40 or higher
Histological evidence of PBC
Need 2 or more of the above criteria in the absence of extrahepatic biliary obstruction.
Name 4 autoimmune diseases which are associated with primary biliary cholangitis.

Sjogren's syndrome (40 - 65%)
Thyroid disease (10-15%)
Limited cutaneous scleroderma (5 - 15%)
Rheumatoid arthritis (5 - 10%)
Most common thyroid disease is Hashimoto's thyroiditis.
Describe the pathophysiology of primary biliary cholangitis.
Continuous T-cell mediated attack on small interlobular bile duct epithelial cells leads to their gradual destruction and disappearance. Causes cholestasis and eventually cirrhosis and liver failure.
No clear trigger has been identified.
Primary biliary cholangitis has a strong preponderance for which gender?
The reason for this is unknown.
Name 5 complications of primary biliary cholangitis.

Liver cirrhosis
Oesophageal varices
Hepatocellular carcinoma
Metabolic bone disease
Malabsorption leading to fat-soluble vitamin deficiency
Vitamins A, D, E and K

Unlike thyroglobulin (Tg) and thyroid peroxidase (TPO) antibodies, TSH receptor autoantibodies are specific to Graves' disease.
Name the preferred firstline thioamide for treatment of hyperthyroidism in non-pregnant adults.

For a young patient with mild hyperthyroidism of short duration with a small goitre due to Graves' disease, what is the preferred treatment approach?
Thioamide (carbimazole) for 12 - 18 months followed by withdrawal to assess for remission
Name the most common feature of Graves' disease which affects nearly all patients?

Name 3 indications for the use of iodine therapy (Lugol's solution) in the treatment of hyperthyroidism.
