Iodine acutely (within hours) inhibits thyroid hormone secretion. It also inhibits iodine organification in the thyroid gland, thereby diminishing thyroid hormone biosynthesis (Wolff-Chaikoff effect).
Describe the mechanism of action of iodine in the treatment of hyperthyroidism.

Acutely inhibits hormonal secretion (within hours)
Inhibition of the iodine organification in the thyroid gland (Wolff-Chaikoff effect)
Effect is maximal after 10 days of treatment.
Why is iodine given preoperatively for patients with Graves' disease undergoing thyroidectomy?
Iodine decreases the vascularity of the thyroid gland and surgical blood loss.
Name 2 factors which contribute to hypercholesterolaemia in primary biliary cholangitis.

Lipoprotein-X is an abnormal lipoprotein particle within the LDL region that is rich in free cholesterol and is increased in cholestasis. Lipoprotein-X reduces the atherogenicity of LDL cholesterol by preventing LDL oxidation.

LDL receptors are reduced in injured hepatocytes which leads to elevated serum choelsterol levels in patients with choelstatic liver disease.
Approximately 75% of patients with primary biliary cholangitis have marked hypercholesterolaemia. What is the effect on cardiovascular disease incidence?
Risk of cardiovascular disease is not increased.
Only patients with metabolic syndrome had increased cardiovascular risk. Patients with PBC should be screened every 2 years for metabolic syndrome.
Name the preferred lipid lowering agent in patients with PBC and ongoing cholestasis.

Statin therapy should be avoided in patients with significant cholestasis as they are excreted into bile and may accumulate leading to toxicity. Ursodeoxycholic acid and obeticholic acid are used in the management of PBC, and these drus also reduce lipid levels. Fibrate therapy is used where there is persistent cholestasis despite treatment with ursodeoxycholic acid/obeticholic acid.
What is the effect of ursodeoxycholic acid and obeticholic acid on hypercholesterolaemia in patients with primary biliary cholangitis?
These drugs result in increased catabolism of cholesterol into primary bile acids and reduced intestinal absorption of cholesterol.
Describe the mechanism by which hepatobiliary disorders cause increased serum alkaline phosphatase (ALP).
Damaged liver tissue regurgitates hepatic alkaline phosphatase into the serum.
Describe how you can distinguish between hepatobiliary and bone source of elevated serum alkaline phosphatase?
Most labs do not distinguish between the different isoenzymes of ALP and just measure other ezymes whose elevation reflect liver disease.
Serum alkaline phosphatase is derived from which 4 sources?
What is the main reason serum gamma-glutamyl transpeptidase (GGT) is useful when investigating elevated serum alkaline phosphatase?
To distinguish between the different sources of alkaline phosphatase (hepatobiliary, bone, placenta).
Serum GGT is not elevated in bone disease or pregnancy.
Name the most common portal of entry for group D streptococcus (Streptococcus gallolyticus)?
Bacteraemia due to group D streptococcus is strongly associated with colorectal cancer.
Of the group D streptococci, which major species has the strongest association with colorectal malignancy and endocarditis?
Which group D streptococci are most strongly associated with biliary tract disease and polymicrobial infection?
Streptoccocus gallolytics subspecies pasteurianus and Streptococcus infantarius
Describe the microbiological features of group D streptococcus.

Gram positive
Hydrolyze esculine
Grow on agar in the presence of 40% bile
Describe the mechanism(s) of action of glucagon-like peptide-1 receptor agonists.

Increase glucose-dependent insulin secretion
Slowed gastric emptying
Reduction of postprandial glucagon
Decreased appetite
Oral glucose has a greater stimulatory effect on insulin secretion than IV glucose.

The incretin effect is due to the gastrointestinal peptides glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1) and glucose-dependent insulinotropic polypeptide (GIP). GLP-1 is secreted from the small intestine in response to nutrients.
Name the 2 main peptides responsible for the incretin effect.
The incretin effect refers to oral glucose having a greater stimulatory effect on insulin secretion than intravenous glucose.
Glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1) is a gastrointestinal peptide which is secreted in response to?
Glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1) is secreted by what cells?
GLP-1 is produced from the proglucagon gene in L-cells of the small intestine.
GLP-1 exerts its main effect by stimulating glucose-dependent insulin release from the pancreatic islet cells.
In which organ is angiotensinogen produced?
Prorenin (the precurosr to renin) is synthesized by what specialised cell type?
Juxtaglomerular cells located in the afferent arteriole of the glomerulus
Where are the juxtaglomerular cells located?
Name the most common cause of inherited colorectal cancer.
What is the pattern of inheritance in hereditary non-polyposis colorectal cancer (Lynch syndrome)?
Autosomal dominant due to a germline mutation in one of several DNA mismatch repair genes.
Name the most common extracolonic tumour associated with hereditary non-polyposis colorectal cancer (Lynch syndrome).
Other cancers include ovarian, gastric, small bowel, hepatobiliary, renal pelvis, ureter, glioma and sebaceous neoplasms.
Colorectal cancers due to hereditary non-polyposis colorectal cancer most commonly occur where?
Name the mismatch repair genes that are associated with hereditary non-polyposis colorectal cancer (Lynch syndrome). (5)
DNA mismatches commonly occur in regions of repetitive nucleotide sequences known as?
Expansion or contraction of the microsatellite regions.

This is a characteristic of tumours which occur as a result of DNA mismatch errors. DNA mismatch errors are most likely to occur in the microsatellite regions (regions of repetitive nucleotide sequences).
What is the usual first step in the diagnostic evaluation for an individual with suspected hereditary non-polyposis colorectal cancer?
Immunohistochemistry testing for lack of expression of DNA mismatch repair protein.
Alternatively can perform microsatellite instability DNA testing. Detected as loss of staining of the MMR protein.
Describe the histological features of colorectal cancer associated with hereditary non-polyposis colorectal cancer.

More commonly mucinous, signet ring cell or medullary type
Poorly differentiated
Brisk lymphocytic infiltrate
At what hepatic venous pressure gradient do varices develop?
At a hepatic venous pressure gradient of 10mmHg
Describe the four components of the Mayo Clinic diagnostic criteria for Takotsubo cardiomyopathy (stress cardiomyopathy).

Transient left ventricular systolic dysfunction
Absence of obstructive coronary artery disease
New electrocardiographic abnormalities or modest troponin elevation
Absence of pheochromocytoma or myocarditis
Wall motion abnormalities are typically regional and extend beyond a single epicardial coronary distribution.
Cardiomyopathy most commonly affects which demographic?
Women account for 89.9% of patients and the mean age of diagnosis is 66.4 years.
Describe the current prevailing theory regarding the pathogenesis of Takotsubo (stress) cardiomyopathy.
Unclear pathogenesis, possibly related to catecholamine release.
Describe the most common ECG abnormalities seen in Takotsubo (stress) cardiomyopathy.
Other abnormalities include QT prolongation, T wave inversion and abnormal Q waves.
Describe how the hepatic venous pressure gradient is calculated.
HVPG is calculated by subtracting the free hepatic venous pressure from the wedged hepatic venous pressure.
The above values are obtained by hepatic vein catheterization.
Portal hypertension is present if the hepatic venous pressure gradient is greater than?
Portal hypertension becomes clinically significant when the hepatic venous pressure gradient is > 10 mmHg, at which point vacies may develop.
At what hepatic venous pressure gradient are patients at risk for developing variceal bleeding and development of ascites?
What is the hepatic venous pressure gradient?

The hepatic venous pressure gradient is used to approximate the gradient in pressure between the portal vein and the inferior vena cava. It can quantify the degree of portal hypertension due to sinusoidal resistance to blood flow.
What is the normal range of a hepatic venous pressure gradient?
Name the most common cause of portal hypertension in developed countries.
Name the most common cause of portal hypertension in developing countries.
Name the the two known genetic mutations which cause autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease.

Chromosome 16 PKD1 locus (78% of patients)
Chromosome 14 PKD2 locus (14% of patients)
PKD2 has a less severe phenotype than PKD1. End stage renal disease 74 vs 54.3 years.
Which genetic mutation causing autosomal polycystic kidney disease has a more severe phenotype?
Name the most common symptom reported by patients with polycystic kidney disease.
Flank pain can be de to renal haemorrhage, calculi or urinary tract infection.
At what stage of life do the majority of patients with polycstic kidney disease develop hypertension?
At what stage of life does renal function begin to decline in most patients with autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease?
Once eGFR begins to decline, the average reduction is 4.4 to 5.9 mL/minute per year.
Name the pathogen most commonly implicated in travellers' diarrhoea.
Incidence of each pathogen varies according to the location of acquisition.
Name the pathogen most commonly implicated in travellers' diarrhoea on cruise ships.
In which patient groups is prophylaxis for travellers' diarrhoea recommended?
Travellers with significant underlying disease travelling to high-risk areas (type 1 diabetes mellitus, immunocompromise, active inflammatory bowel disease, heart or kidney failure).
What is the recommended antibiotic prophylaxis for travellers' diarrhoea?
Chemoprophylaxis is not recommended for healthy patients. Limit to no longer than 3 weeks.
Name three different urinary patterns seen in diseases of the glomerulus.
Name the 2 most common causes of nephrotic syndrome in adults.
Name 2 noncalcium-containing binders for treatment of hyperphosphataemia.
Antibodies directed against which 2 transmembrane receptors on the podocyte is suggestive of primary membranous nephropathy?
Approximately 70% of patients with primary membranous nephropathy will have autoantibodies against PLA2R.
Describe the charactersistic histologic lesion on light microscopy in membranous nephropathy.

Diffuse thickening of the glomerular basement membrane throughout all glomeruli.
Absence of hypercellularity.
Describe the findings on immunofluorescence microscopy in membranous nephropathy.
Diffuse granular pattern of immunoglobulin G and C3 staining along the glomerular basement membrane.
IgG4 is the predominant IgG subclass.
Describe the natural history of membranous nephropathy.

30% spontaneous complete remission
30% spontaneous partial remission
30% end stage renal failure
Name 4 drugs which may cause secondary membranous nephropathy.
Name the most common IgG subtype seen in primary (idiopathic) membranous nephropathy.
Anti-PLA2R antibodies are identified in what percentage of patients with primary membranous nephropathy?
What is the role of non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers (verapamil, diltiazem) in heart failure with reduced ejection fraction?
Should be avoided in heart failure as no mortality benefit and some agents may worsen outcomes.
What is the role of dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers in heart failure with reduced ejection fraction?

Safe to be used for treatment of hypertension or angina.
Should only be used in patients already on ACEi/ARB and ß-blockers as these agents have a mortality benefit.
Name 5 medications which improve survival in patients with heart failure with reduced ejection fraction.

Angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitors (ACEi)
Angiotensin II receptor blockers (ARB)
ß-blockers
Aldosterone antagonists
Angiotensin-receptor neprilysin inhibitors (ARNI)
When is ivabradine indicated in heart failure with reduced ejection fraction?

Symptomatic chronic heart failure (NYHA 2 - 3) with LVEF ≤ 35% in sinus rhythm with a heart rate ≥ 77 beats per minute despite maximum tolerated ß blocker therapy.
Improves LV function and quality of life, but not mortality or hospitalisation.
Describe the mechanism of action of ivabradine.
Selective inhibitor of the sinoatrial pacemaker modulating "f-current". Slows sinus rate by prolonging the slow depolarization phase.
Name 5 contraindications to use of ivabradine.

Acute decompensated heart failure
Blood pressure less than 90/50mmHg
Sick sinus syndrome, sinoatrial block or third degree atrioventicular block
Pacemaker dependence
Severe hepatic impairment

Bradycardia
Phosphenes (transient areas of enhanced brightness in the visual fields)
Name 2 factors that lead to incomplete calcium absorption from the gut.

Activated vitamin D is required for intestinal calcium abosrption
Calcium combines with certain anions in the intestinal lumen to form insoluble salts (e.g. calcium phosphate and calcium oxalate)
Parathyroid hormone (PTH) is secreted by the parathyroid glands in response to?
Decreases in plasma ionized calcium sensed by the calcium-sensing receptor (CaSR)
Which form of calcium is filtered by the glomerulus?
The majority of calcium is passively reabsorbed in which part of the nephron?
70% is reabsorbed passively in the proximal tubule
The majority of calcium and phosphate in the body exists in what form?
Bone acts as a clacium reservoir and is involved in maintaining normal plasma ionized calcium
What is the primary cause of tubulointerstitial nephritis and ureteral stenosis in renal transplant patients?
BK virus nephropathy affects approximately what percentage of renal transplant patients?
How do patients with BK virus nephropathy typically present?
Slowly progressive rise in the serum creatinine concentration 10 - 13 months after transplantation.
Typically causes no clinical signs or symptoms of infection.
BK virus nephropathy typically occurs how long after transplantation?
On urine cytology, what type of cell is suggestive of BK virus nephropathy?
Describe the urinalysis findings seen in patients with BK virus nephropathy?

Pyuria
Haematuria
Cellular casts consisting of renal tubular cells and inflammatory cells
Name 2 findings on renal biopsy required to definitively make a diagnosis of BK virus nephropathy.

Characteristic cytopathic changes
Positive immunohistochemistry testing using antibodies directed specifically against BK or against the cross-reacting SV40 large T antigen
Regarding immunosuppressants, what is considered the most important risk factor for developing BK virus nephropathy?
The type of agent is not thought to contribute significantly.
Acute kidney injury due to aminoglycosides is through what mechanism?
Relatively common complication of aminoglycoside therapy. About 10 - 20% of patients develop a 50% increase in serum creatinine from baseline.
The majority of uric acid is produced by what organ?
Uric acid is not ingested, but diet provides a significant source of urate precursors.
Urate is produced from the breakdown of purine mononucleotides into the purine bases guanine and hypoxanthine. These are then oxidized to produce uric acid.
Name the 2 routes of excretion of uric acid.
Excreted intact by the gut and the kidney.
Majority of excretion (60%) is via the urine.
What is the most common mechanism for primary or secondary hyperuricaemia?
Decreased renal uric acid excretion (accounts for 85 - 90%)
Name the most common subtype of extranodal marginal zone lymphoma.
Name the most common extraintestinal manifestation of ulcerative colitis.
Name the most common cause of ascites.
Name 3 laboratory investigation results suggestive of intravascular haemolysis.

Presence of free haemoglobin in the plasma (haemoglobinaemia)
Presence of free haemoglobin in the urine (haemoglobinuria)
Haemosiderin in a stained urine sediment
Describe the difference between intravascular and extravascular haemolysis.

Intravascular haemolysis refers to haemolysis that occurs when the red blood cells are still in the circulation.
Extravascular haemolysis occurs via the reticuloendthelial macrophages and monocytes of the liver, spleen, bone marrow and lymph nodes.
The major factor which determines where haemolysis occurs is the severity of the RBC membrane defect.
Describe the metabolic abnormalities seen in tumour lysis syndrome.
Describe the mechanism by which tumour lysis syndrome causes hypocalcaemia.
Phosphorous concentration in malignant cells is significantly higher than in normal cells. Hyperphosphataemia leads to secondary hypocalcaemia due to increased production of calcium phosphate.
Hydrogen ions in the urine must be buffered  in the urine to prevent it becoming too acidic. What is it buffered with?
Under normal circumstances, how much bicarbonate is excreted in the urine?

85 - 90% of filtered bicabronate is reclaimed by the proximal tubule
10% of bicarbonate is reclaimed in the distal nephron via H-ATPase and H-K ATPase.
Where is the majority of filtered bicarbonate reclaimed in the nephron?
85 - 90% is reclaimed in the proximal tubule
10% of bicarbonate is reclaimed in the distal nephron via H-ATPase and H-K ATPase.
All forms of renal tubular acidosis result in what metabolic disturbance?
Name the 2 mechanisms which result in a normal anion gap metabolic acidosis in renal tubular acidosis.

Net retention of hydrochloric acid or a salt metabolised to hydrochloric acid
Net loss of sodium bicarbonate or equivalent
Which 2 organs are responsible for maintenance of acid-base balance.

Alveolar ventilation removes carbon dioxide
Kidneys reclaim filtered bicarbonate and excrete hydrogen ions.
What are the 4 types of renal tubular acidosis?

Type 1 (classic) distal renal tubular acidosis
Type 2 proximal renal tubular acidosis
Voltage-dependent renal tubular acidosis
Type 4 hypoaldosteronism
What is the mechanism by which a normal anion gap metabolic acidosis occurs in type 1 (clasic) distal renal tubular acidosis?
Impaired hydrogen ion secretion in the distal nephron
In patients with untreated type 1 (classic) distal renal tubular acidosis, what would the expected plasma bicarbonate concentration?
In type 1 (classic) distal renal tubular acidosis, what is the expected concentration of potassium?
What 2 types of renal tubular acidosis may result in hypokalaemia?
Renal tubule production of ammonia is increased in response to?
Which blood product type carries the highest risk transfusion-transmitted bacterial infection?
Platelets are stored at room temperature.
What is the major factor that determines the site of haemolysis (i.e intravascular vs extravascular)?
The severity of the red blood cell membrane defect.
Intravascular haemolysis occurs when there is considerable structural damage to the RBC membrane (e.g. mechanical shearing).
Using Prussian blue staining (iron stain) on urine sediment.
What are the main sites of haemolysis in extravascular haemolysis?
Macrophages of the reticuloendothelial system in the liver, spleen, bone marrow and lymph nodes.

Severely damaged RBCs, especially those coated with complement, are primarily destroyed in the liver.
Poorly deformable RBCs such as spherocytes or sickled cells are primarily destroyed in the spleen in the cords of Billroth.
In intravascular haemolysis, what would be the expected effect on haptoglobin levels?
Intravascular haemolysis causes free haemoglobin to be released into the plasma (haemoglobinaemia) which is immediately bound by haptoglobin. This often causes undetectable levels of haptoglobin.
Haemoglobin-haptoglobin complex is cleared almost immediately from plasma by what organ?
In plasma, the majority of uric acid circulates as?
Which cell type produces gastric acid?
The antrum of the stomach contains G-cells which are located in the pyloric glands.
The cephalic phase of gastric acid secretion stimulates gastric secretion via what mechanism?
Describe how chronic kidney disease leads to a metabolic acidosis.
As the number of functioning nephrons declines, there is reduced production of ammonia (ammonia buffers hydrogen ions in the urine).
At approximately what glomerular filtration rate does total ammonium excretion begin to fall?
In metabolic acidosis due to chronic kidney disease, what is the expected anion gap?
Anion gap typically remains normal until late stages of chronic kidney disease.
In late stages anion gap begins to widen due to retention of anions such as phosphate, sulphate, urate and hippurate.
What are the benefits of alkali (sodium bicarbonate) therapy in patients with metabolic acidosis due to chronic kidney disease?

Slows progression of chronic kidney disease
Prevention of bone buffering (bone resorption/osteopenia)
What is the most common cause of primary glomerulonephrtis in developed countries?
In what age group does peak incidence of IgA nephropathy occur?
How is a diagnosis of IgA nephropthy confirmed?
IgA nephropathy is established only by kidney biopsy demonstrating immunofluorescence microscopy demonstrating IgA deposits.

IgA nephropathy often follows a benign course. Biopsy is only performed if there are signs suggestive of more severe or peogressive disease (e.g. urine protein excretion >500mg/day or elevated serum creatinine).
Describe how patients with IgA nephropathy typically present.

40 - 50% present with visible haematuria, often accompanying an upper respiratory infection ("synpharyngitic haematuria")
30 - 40% have microscopic haematuria incidentally detected on screening investigations
10% with either nephrotic syndrome or an acute, rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis.
In what circumstances would a kidney biopsy be performed in a patient with IgA nephropathy
Generally only performed if there are signs suggestive of severe or progressive disease (e.g. proteinuria of at least 500mg/day or elevated serum creatinine).
Describe the mechanism by which heart failure causes hyponatraemia.
Heart failure impairs the ability to excrete ingested water by increasing antidiuretic hormone (ADH) levels.

When cardiac output and systemic blood pressure are reduced, renin (and subsequent angiotensin II formation), ADH are increased. Although patients with heart failure are oedematous and have increased plasma and extracellular fluid volumes, the body perceives volume depletion since the low cardiac output decreases the pressure perfusing the baroreceptors in the carotid sinus and the renal afferent arteriole.
What is the relationship between hyponatraemia in heart failure and mortality?
Hyponatraemia is a predictor of mortality, it parallels progression of heart disease.
Where is the majority of T3 formed?
Approximately 80% of T3 is formed by deiodination of T4 in extrathyroidal tissues.
The conversion of T4 (thyroxine) to T3 (triiodothyronine) is catalyzed by what enzymes?
Type 1 is the predominant deiodinating enzyme in the liver, kidney and thyroid. Type 2 deiodinase is the predominant deiodinating enzyme in muscle, brain, pituitary, skin and placenta.
Which type of deiodinase is blocked by propylthiouracil?
Approximately 80% of T3 is produced in extrathyroidal tissue via deiodination of T4. Type 1 deiodinase is responsible for the majority of extrathyroidally produced T3.
Which type of deiodinase is responsible for the majority of extrathyroidally produced T3?
T4 is solely produced in the thyroid gland
The vast majority of thyroid hormone (both T4 and T3) is bound to which serum protein?
How is iodine transported into thyroid follicular cells?

The sodium iodine transporter is an intrinsic transmembrane protein located on the membrane of thyroid follicular cells. Iodide is transported into thyroid follicular cells against a chemical and electrical gradient.
The oxidation and binding of iodine to thyroglobin tyrosine residues is catalyzed by what enzyme?
The thyroid gland contains large quantities of T4 and T3 stored within what protein?
Thyroid hormone is also synthesized within thyroglobulin.
What is the effect of a dopamine infusion on serum TSH?
Will cause it to drop rapidly by a small amount.
What is the likelihood of hypoglycaemia in a patient being treated with a glucagon-like peptide-1 receptor agonist (GLP1 agonist)?
Usually do not cause hypoglycaemia alone.
Increased risk of hypoglycaemia in combination with a sulfonylurea or insulin.
What is the effect of type 2 diabetes mellitus on the incretin effect?
Patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus typically have little or no incretin-mediated augmentation of insulin secretion.
Effect is due to decreased secretion of GLP-1 and loss of the insulinotropic effects of GIP.
In what type of diabetes mellitus are glucagon-like peptide-1 receptor (GLP-1) agonists indicated?
Not approved for use in type 1 diabetes mellitus.
Glucagon-like peptide-1 has a short half life of 1-2 minutes due to degradation by what enzyme?
What is the most common side effect of glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1) agonists?
Nausea and vomiting are common side effects (up to 50%) but usually improve with ongoing treatment.
Glucagon-like peptide-1 receptor agonists are contraindicated in creatinine clearance less than?
What is the effect of glucagon-like peptide-1 agonists on weight?
Due to its effect on slowing gastric emptying GLP-1 analogues cause weight loss.
What is the initial testing for suspected primary hyperaldoesteronism?
Plasma renin activity and plasma aldosterone concentration.
When is the optimal way to collect plasma renin activity (PRA) and plasma aldosterone concentration?
Sample should be obtained in the morning while seated.
What is the effect of sodium-glucose co-transporter 2 (SGLT2) inhibitors on weight?
What is the mechanism of action of sodium-glucose co-transporter 2 inhibitors?
Cause hypoglycaemia by increasing urinary glucose excretion
SGLT2 inhibitors completely block proximal tubular glucose reabsorption.
What is the likelihood of hypoglycaemia in a patient being treated with a sodium-glucose co-transporter 2 inhibitor?
Unlikely to cause hypoglycaemia when used as monotherapy.
Tumour lysis syndrome may lead to acute kidney injury via what mechanism?
Catabolism of the nucleic acids leads to hyperuricaemia, and the marked increase in uric acid excretion can lead to preciptation of uric acid in the renal tubules leading to acute kidney injury.
Causes renal vasoconstriction, impaired autoregulation, decreased renal blood flow and inflammation.
What is the most common type of takotsubo cardiomyopathy?
What is the pattern of cardiac biomarker abnormalities in takotsubo cardiomyopathy?

Serum cardiac troponin levels are elevated in most patients
Creatine kinase levels are generally normal or mildly elevated

Pre-hepatic (e.g. portal vein thrombosis)
Hepatic (e.g. cirrhosis)
Post-hepatic (e.g. Budd-Chiari syndrome)
Portal hypertension develops when there is resistance to portal blood flow. Resistance most often occurs within the liver (as is the case in cirrhosis).
Name 5 causes of metabolic acidosis resulting in an increased anion gap metabolic acidosis.
Name 4 causes of a normal anion gap metabolic acidosis.

Diarrhoea or other intestinal losses
Renal tubular acidosis
Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors
Chronic kidney disease
Give a definition for lactic acidosis.
What is the most common cause of metabolic acidosis in hospitalised patients?
How do patients with IgG4 disease typically present?
Usually present with subacute development of a mass in the affected organ (e.g. orbital pseudotumour, renal mass, lung nodules) or diffuse enlargement of an organ.

Multiple organs are affected in 60 - 90%.
Symptoms of allergy are present in 40%.
Weight loss of 9 - 14kg over months is common in multiorgan disease.
Describe management of IgG4 related disease.
Corticosteroids are the first-line agent for inducing remission.
Optimal treatment has not been established.
Name 3 clinical predictors of progression to end stage renal failure in IgA nephropathy.
Patients with recurrent episodes of gross haematuria without proteinuria are at low risk for progressive kidney disease.
What is the most important contributing factor in the pathogenesis of uraemic bleeding?
Cause of uraemic bleeding is multifactorial. Platelet dysfunction is due to both decreased platelet aggregation and impaired platelet adhesiveness.
In a patient with uraemic bleeding, what are the expected results of levels circulating coagulation factors, prothrombin time and activated thromboplastin time (APTT)?

Coagulation factor levels are normal
There is no prolongation of prothrombin or partial thromboplastin times.
Re-calcifying citrated plasma in the presence of tissue factor and phospholipid and measuring the time it takes to form a fibrin clot.

Citrate in the blue top collection tube chelates calcium in blood so that coagulation is unable to proceed. Calcium is required for the assembly of coagulation factor complexes on activated cell surfaces or phospholipids.
What is the simplest, most rapidly acting and least toxic acute treatment for platelet dysfunction in uraemic patients?
Appears to act by increasing the release of large factor VIII : von Willebrand factor multimers from endothelial cells.
Name 5 treatment options for patients with uraemic bleeding.

Desmopressin (DDAVP)
Correction of anaemia (blood transfusion or erythropoeisis stimulating agents)
Dialysis
Oestrogen
Cryoprecipitate
How does desmopressin (DDAVP) help treat uraemic bleeding?
Increases plasma levels of von Willebrand factor, factor VIII from endothelial cells.
What are the features of vitamin B12 deficiency (megaloblastic anaemia) on peripheral blood smear?

Anaemia
Macrocytic red blood cells
Mild leukopenia and/or thrombocytopenia
Low reticulocyte count
Hypersegmented neutrophils
Which cell type secretes intrinsic factor?
Describe the process by which vitamin B12 (cobalamin) is absorbed?

In food Vitamin B12 is bound to proteins, which are dissociated in the acid milleu of the stomach with the help of pepsin.
Vitamin B12 is then bound by haptocorrin (R-protein, R-factor) secreted in the saliva to protect it from the acidic environment.
In the duodenum pancreatic proteases cleave haptocorrin, releasing vitamin B12 in its free form.
Vitamin B12 is then bound by intrinsic factor.
B12-IF complex is then taken up by cubilin receptors in the ileum.
What is the name of the protein which binds to Vitamin B12 to protect it from the acidic environment in the stomach?

Haptocorrin is secreted in the saliva. Once past the acidic environment of the stomach, haptocorrin is cleaved from Vitamin B12 by pancreatic proteases. Vitamin B12 is then bound to intrinsic factor and the B12-IF complex is absorbed via the cubilin receptors in the ileum.
Once vitamin B12 has been bound by intrinsic factor it can be absorbed in the ileum via what receptor?
Haptocorrin (R-binders, R-factor, R-protein) is secreted where?
Haptocorrin is a glycoprotein which is produced by the salivary glands.
In what types of foods is vitamin B12 present?
Meats, dairy, eggs, clams and liver.
People with what type of diet are at risk of vitamin B12 deficiency?
Vitamin B12 is found in animal products (meats, dairy, eggs). Highest concentratioins are in clams and liver.
Megaloblastic anaemia can cause haemolysis. Will there by a reticulocytosis?
Unlike other forms of haemolytic anaemia, the reticulocyte count in vitamin B12 and folate deficiency is also low because RBC production is affected.
Why is daptomycin not recommended in the treatment of pneumonia?
Daptomycin is inactivated by pulmonary surfactant.
Between Enterococcus faecalis and Enterococcus faecium, which isolate is more likely to cause endocarditis?
Between Enterococcus faecalis and Enterococcus faecium, which isolate is more likely to be resistant to ampicillin?
What is the antibiotic class of moxifloxacin?
Describe the mechanism of action of moxifloxacin.
Bactericidal; inhibit bacterial DNA synthesis by blocking DNA gyrase and topoisomerase IV.
Describe the mechanism of action of fluoroquinolones (moxifloxacin, ciprofloaxcin, norfloxacin).
Bactericidal; inhibit bacterial DNA synthesis by blocking DNA gyrase and topoisomerase IV.
What are the potential serious adverse reactions to fluoroquinolones?
Alpha thalassaemia is typically caused by what type of genetic defect (mutation or deletion)?
Alpha thalassaemia is usually caused by gene deletions rather than gene mutations.
There are 4 alpha globin genes encoded by an adjacent pair on each chromosome. Severity of disease increases with loss of the alleles.
In alpha thalassaemia, what type of genetic defect (deletion or mutation) causes more severe disease?
Non-deletional mutant alleles such as haemoglobin constant spring (CS) tend to be associated with more severe phenotypes than deletional alleles.
How many alpha globin genes are there?
There are 4 alpha globin genes, encoded by an adjacent pair of each chromosome.
Describe the clinical phenotype seen in patients with loss of all 4 alpha globin genes (--/--).
Does moxifloxacin have activity against Pseudomonas aeruginosa?
No, moxifloxacin has less activity against Pseudomonas aeruginosa than ciprofloxacin.
Does moxifloxacin have activity against Streptococcus pneumoniae?
Yes, used in treatment of moderate - severe community acquired pneumonia in patients who have immediate penicillin hypersensitivity
Which fluoroquinolone (moxifloxacin or ciprofloxacin) has the best activity against Streptococcus pneumoniae?
What is the genetic defect in patients with haemoglobin H disease?
Usually loss of three alpha-chain genes: --/a-.
Can also be non-deletional: (--/aat) where t stands for a mutant alpha chain such as Hb constant spring.
Describe the usual phenotype seen in haemoglobin H disease.

Thalassaemia intermedia phenotype.
Usually transfusion-independent, but may deteriorate into transfusion dependence (pregnancy, sepsis).
Typically have a mild anaemia with a MCV between 62 - 70fL
The genetic defect - - / a - involving the alpha globin genes will result in what disease?
Alpha thalassaemia minima is due to what genetic defect in the alpha chain genes?

a - / a a
Loss of a single alpha-chain gene.
Results in a benign carrier state where affected individuals are not anaemic and red blood cells are not microcytic.
Do fluoroquinolones have activity against Gram-negative bacteria?
Yes, ciprofloxacin is particularly active against Gram-negative organisms (e.g. Pseudomonas, Shigella, Salmonella).
Do fluoroquinolones have activity against Legionella species?
Yes, combination therapy with azithromycin and ciprofloxacin is recommended in very severe cases of Legionella pneumonia only.
What is the treatment for mild to moderate Legionella pneumonia in adults?
Which step is the rate-limiting step of the renin-angiotensin system cascade?
Renin cleavage of angiotensin I from angiotensinogen
Name 3 indications where ACE inhibitors are the antihypertensive of choice.

Heart failure with reduced ejection fraction
Proteinuric chronic kidney disease (diabetic and non-diabetic)
After myocardial infarction in most patients
Angiotensin converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors cause a decline in blood pressure due to decreased formation of what peptide hormone?

The above image summarises the phases of the cardiac action potential. Describe what occurs in phase 0.

Phase 0 is depolarization. Fast sodium channels open and the membrane potential becomes more positive. Voltage gated sodium channels (fast sodium channels) open and permit sodium to rapidly flow into the cell and depolarise it.
The above image summarises the phases of the cardiac action potential. Describe what occurs in phase 1.
Phase 1 is initial repolarization. Fast sodium channels close, the cell beings to repolarize, and potassium ions leave the cell through open potassium channels.
The above image summarises the phases of the cardiac action potential. Describe what occurs in phase 2.

Phase 2 is plateau. Calcium channels open (and calcium enters the cell) and fast potassium channels close. A plateua is generated by a balance of repolarizing potassium currents and depolarizing calcium current.
The above image summarises the phases of the cardiac action potential. Describe what occurs in phase 3.

Phase 3 is rapid repolarization. Calcium channels close and slow potassium channels open. The closure of calcium ion channels and increased potassium ion permability permits potassium ions to rapidly exit the cell, ending the plateau and returning the cell membrane potential to its resting level.
The above image summarises the phases of the cardiac action potential. Describe what occurs in phase 4.
Phase 4 reflects the resting membrane potential, which averages about -90 millivolts.

Which has the higher potassium concentration: serum or plasma?
Serum. Clotting causes potassium to move out of cells.
This is why patients with extreme thrombocytosis have pseudohyperkalaemia.
Why do patients with thrombocytosis develop pseudohyperkalaemia?

Potassium moves out of cells after clotting has occured. This leads to a higher concentration of potassium in serum than in plasma (this is usually not significantly different in patients with normal platelets). In patients with marked thrombocytosis, this can result in pseudohyperkalaemia.
What is the most common cause of pseudohyperkalaemia?
Two mechanisms: mechanical trauma during venipuncture and repeated fist clenching. Muscle uses causes potassium to move out of cells.

Give a definition for lacunar infarct.
Small (0.2 - 15mm in diameter) non-cortical infarcts caused by occlusion of a single penetrating branch of a large cerebral artery.

Lacunar infarcts are small noncortical infarcts caused by occlusion of a single penetrating branch of a large cerebral artery. Penetrating branches arise at acute angles from the large arteries of {{c1::the circle of Willis}}, stem of the {{c1::middle cerebral artery}}, or the {{c1::basilar artery}}.
Most lacunes occur in the {{c1::basal ganglia (putamen, globus pallidus, thalamus, caudate)}}, {{c1::subcortical white matter (internal capsule and corona radiata)}}, and {{c1::pons}}.

Strongyloides stercoralis infection is endemic to what areas?

Rural areas of tropical and subtropical regions
Some remote Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities in Australia have prevalence up to 60%.
In Australia, what patient groups should be considered for testing for strongyloidiasis?

Residents of endemic areas
Immigrants
Refugees
Recent travellers to endemic areas
How does infection with Strongyloides stercoralis begin?
Infection begins when human skin contacts filariform larvae (the infective larval stage). Found in soil or other materials contaminated with human faeces.
After penetrating the skin, Strongyloides stercoralis filariform larvae migrate via haematogenous spread to what organ?
Filariform larvae penetrate the skin and migrate haematogenously to the lungs where they penetrate into the alveolar air sacs.
What is unique about Strongyloides stercoralis lifecycle compared to other helminthic parasites?
S. stercoralis can complete its life cycle entirely within the human host.
What abnormality of blood tests may be the only clue that a patient has Strongyloides stercoralis infection?
What is the significance of suppression of cell-mediated immunity in patients with strongyloidiasis?
Can lead to overwhelming hyperinfection and death (including short courses of corticosteroids of 6 - 17 days)
Describe the symptoms which may be seen in strongyloidiasis.

Upper abdominal pain due to duodenitis
Diarrhoea
Nausea and vomiting
Dry cough, throat irritation
Haemoptysis
Describe how autoinfection occurs in patients with strongyloidiasis.

Rhabditiform larvae (which normally pass in the faeces) may mature into filariform larvae within the gastrointestinal tract. Filariform larvae can then penetrate the perianal skin or colonic mucosa to complete the cycle of autoinfection.
A patient is about to undergo a renal transplant and you notice an isolated eosinophilia on the full blood count. What disease should you screen for before immunosuppressing this patient?
Strongyloidiasis. Immunosuppression can result in hyperinfection and subsequent death.
Describe the diagnostic workup of a patient with suspected strongyloidiasis.

Stool culture using modified agar plate (low sensitivity). Take at least 2 samples.
Strongyloides serology (ELISA used to detect IgG to filariform larvae)
How can travellers avoid being infected with Strongyloides stercoralis?
Wearing shoes in order to avoid contact with infected soil
In patients from a high-level care nursing home, what is the most commonly implicated organism in pneumonia?
Describe the aetiology of tropical sprue.
Most patients have overgrowth of toxigenic coliform bacteria (Klebsiella, E. Coli and Enterobacter) in the small bowel. No specific causative infectious agent has been isolated.
Tropical sprue affects what part of the bowel?
Tropical sprue occurs in countries located where?
Occurs in the tropics in a narrow band north and south of the equator to 30 degrees latitude. (Does not affect all countries within this band).
Name 6 countries in which tropical sprue is prevalent.
How long do travellers have to stay in an endemic area to develop tropical sprue?
Usually need to stay for more than a month. Seldom seen in travellers who stay less than 2 weeks.
What complications can occur as a result of tropical sprue?

Nutrient malabsorption (including folate and vitamin B12 deficiency)
Megaloblastic anaemia
Name 6 symptoms which may be seen in a patient with tropical sprue.

Chronic diarrhoea
Steatorrhea (most patients)
Cramping, gas
Fatigue
Progressive weight loss
Signs and symptoms of malabsorption are common (glossitis and cheilitis, protuberant abdomen, poedal oedema)
Tropical sprue can lead to vitamin B12, folate deficiency and megaloblastic anaemia. Do these patients develop any neurologic manifestations of vitamin B12 deficiency?
What is the haematological complication of tropical sprue?
Megaloblastic anaemia due to folate and vitamin B12 deficiency

Campylobcater are fragile and easily destroyed by {{c1::heat}}, {{c1::desiccation}}, {{c1::acidity}}, {{c1::irradiation}}, and {{c1::disinfectants}}.

PPIs increase the risk of Campylobacter enteritis as Campylobacters are sensitivie to stomach acidity.

What is the role of macrolides in the treatment of meningitis?
Not indicated for meningitis due to poor penetration into cerebrospinal fluid.

Bacteriostatic; inhibit bacterial protein synthesis by binding to the 50S ribosomal subunit.

Describe the typical EEG findings seen in mesial temporal lobe epilepsy.
Epileptiform sharp waves over the temporal region
In mesial temporal lobe epilepsy, approximately what percentage of patients will have abnormal EEG findings?
With repeated studies, the yield of interictal EEG in mesial temporal lobe epilepsy is over 90%
What is the natural history of mesial temporal lobe epilepsy due to hippocampal sclerosis?
Progressive disorder. Seizures initially controlled with anti-seizure drugs, can re-emerge and become medically intractable in up to 60 - 90% of patients.
Over 80% of cases of temporal lobe epilepsy associated with hippocampal sclerosis manifest before what age?
Describe the typical features of an aura due to temporal lobe epilepsy.
Rising epigastric sensation ("roller coaster" sensation), psychic or experiential phenomena such as déjà vu, jamai vu, or fear.
Can patients with temporal lobe epilepsy recall their aura?
Describe the clinical features of a seizure due to temporal lobe epilepsy.

Focal seizures with impairment of consciousness or awareness (complex partial seizures)
Focal seizures usually manifest as behavioural arrest and staring (last 30 - 120 seconds)
Aura (rising epigastric sensation/"roller coaster" sensation)
Automatisms (repetitive, stereotyped, purposeless movements) typically involving the hands and mouth
Postictal confusion usually resolving within minutes (nose-wiping is common)
Heart rate changes (usually tachycardia)
Describe the automatisms which are commonly seen in patients with temporal lobe epilepsy.
Typically mild, involving the hands (picking fidgeting, fumbling) and mouth (chewing, lip smacking)

Fever
Nuchal rigidity

CD8+ T-lymphocytes which release inflammatory cytokines.

Immunocompromised state

Vasogenic cerebral oedema due to increased permeability of the blood-brain barrier

Because it is unlikely to improve patient outcomes if given after the first dose of antibiotics.

Diabetes mellitus

Following one or more episodes of portal vein pyemia, usually related to bowel leakage and peritonitis.
Direct spread from biliary infection.

A patient with a pyogenic liver abscess with streptococcal or staphyloccocal isolated as a single organism should undero what further evaluation?

Patients with uncomplicated amoebic liver abscess should not undergo drainage, as there has been no benefit observed with drainage in addition to medical therapy.

Praziquantel (adult and child) 20mg/kg orally with food, for 2 doses, given 4 hours apart

Migrate against portal blood flow to the mesenteric venules of the small and large intestine (S. japonicum), mesenteric venules of the colon (S. mansoni), or the vesicale venous plexus (S. haematobium)
In patients with schistosomiasis, disease, inflammation and subsequent fibrosis is due to?

Describe the current theory regarding the pathogenesis of transfusion-related acute lung injury.

Passive transfer of human leukocyte antigen or human neutrophil antigen antibodies found in the donor's plasma are directed against the receipient's leukocyte antigen. The antigen-antibody reaction results in activation of neutrophils in the lung microcirculation, releasing oxidases and proteases that damage blood vessels.

The majority of the fibers in the lateral spinothalamic tract end by synapsing with third order neurons located where?
Ventral posterolateral nucleus of the thalamus
Where do the anterior and lateral spinothalamic tracts decussate?

Within the spinal cord. After synapsing with first order neurons in the substantia gelatinosa in the posterior gray column, the axons of the second-order neurons decussate and ascend in the opposite anterolateral white column.
Injury to the anterior or lateral spinothalamic ascending spinal cord tract (anterolateral system) will produce injury on what side (ipsilateral or contralateral)?
Contralateral. Decussation of the anterior and lateral spinothalamic ascending tracts occurs within the spinal cord.
Poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis is usually preceded by infection with what group of organisms?

No specific treatment. Usuaully supportive (e.g. diuretics to treat hypertension and fluid overload)

Poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis typically occurs in what part of the world?

Excellent. Virtually no long term renal impairment, even in patients who present with acute renal failure with crescents on biopsy.
How can one differentiate IgA nephropathy from poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis clinically?

IgA nephropathy usually has a shorter time between antecedent illness.

How do familial cases of essential thrombocytosis occur?
Not a germline mutation, thought to be due to genetic predisposition to acquire somatic rotations.
Essential thrombocytosis represents approximately what percentage of chronic myeloproliferative neoplasms?
Name 4 predictors of arterial thrombosis in patients with essential thrombocytosis.

Age greater than 60
History of thrombosis
Cardiovascular risk facotrs (smoking, hypertension, diabetes mellitus)
JAK2 V617F mutation
Describe the findings on a full blood examination in a patient with essential thrombocytosis.

Thrombocytosis
Variable platelet size (platelet anisocytosis)
Red blood cells are usually normal
White blood cells are usually normal
Name the most common aetiology of spontaneous intracerebral haemorrhage.
Name the most common cause of non-traumatic lobar intracerebral haemorrhage in the elderly.
Hypertensive haemorrhages most commonly occur in territories provided by what type of blood vessels?
Penetrator arteries that branch off major intracerebral arteries, often at 90 degree angles with the parent vessels.
Describe the differences in location of hypertensive intracerebral haemorrhage vs cerebral amyloid angiopathy.

Cerebral amyloid angiopathy usually manifests with spontaneous lobar haemorrhage.
Hypertensive intracerebral haemorrhage more commonly arsises in the putamen, thalamus and pons.
Describe the most commonly affected areas in hypertensive intracerebral haemorrhage.

Pons and midbrain (penetrators off the basilar artery)
Thalamus (thalamostriate penetrators off the P1 and P2 segements of the posterior cerebral arteries)
Putamen and caudate (lenticulostriate penetrators off the M1 segment of the middle cerebral arteries)
Cerebellum
Describe the typical presentation seen in pontine haemorrhage.

Deep coma of rapid onset
Total paralysis
Pinpoint pupils that react to a strong light source
Horizontal eye movements are absent
Describe the most common location of a spontaneous intracerebral haemorrhage.
Describe the clinical manifestations seen in spontaneous putaminal haemorrhage.
Name 5 risk factors for spontaneous intracerebral haemorrhage.

Hypertension
Age
Presence of cerebral amyloid angiopathy
Antithrombotic therapy
High alcohol intake
Do patients with cerebrellar haemorrhage develop hemiparesis?
Describe the clinical manifestations seen in cerebellar haemorrhage.

Inability to walk
Vomiting
Headache (usually occipital, may be referred to the neck or shoulder)
Neck stiffness
Gaze palsy
Facial weakness

Corticobasal degeneration
Multiple system atrophy
Progressive supranuclear palsy
Name the most frequent initial feature seen in patients with classic progressive supranuclear palsy.
What is the hallmark clinical feature of progressive supranuclear palsy (PSP)?
Early in progressive supranuclear palsy, vertical ophthalmoparesis can be corrected on examination by what manoeuvre?
Oculocephalic manoeuvre (passive flexion and extension of the neck). Tests for the vestibuloocular reflexes.
In immunocompetent hosts, how long does it typically take for herpes zoster lesions to crust over?
When are herpes zoster lesions considered to be no longer infectious?
After 7 - 10 days when they have crusted over.
A sight threatening zoster keratitis or zoster ophthalmicus can result due to involvement of what nerve?
Ophthalmic branch of the trigeminal cranial nerve
Name the most commonly involved sites in herpes zoster.
Name the most common complication of herpes zoster infection.
What factor increases the risk of postherpetic neuralgia following herpes zoster infection?
Describe the triad seen in Ramsay Hunt syndrome (herpes zoster oticus).

Ipsilateral facial paralysis
Ear pain
Vesicles in the auditory canal and auricle
Ramsay Hunt syndrome (herpes zoster oticus) occurs due to reactivation of varicella zoster virus in what ganglion?
Name the most common cause of acute kidney injury in hospitalised patients.
Enterohaemorrhagic Escherichia coli (EHEC) are capable of producing what toxin?
What strain of Escherichia coli is capable of producing Shiga toxin?
Haemolytic-uraemic syndrome (HUS) complicates 6 - 9% of infections due to what bacteria?
What is the typical incubation period between exposure to Enterohaemorrhagic Escherichia coli and onset of symptoms?
What is the most common manifestation of infection with Enterohaemorrhagic Escherichia coli (EHEC)?
Name the bacterial infection most likely to be associated with bloody diarrhoea.
Describe the triad seen in haemolytic uraemic syndrome.

Acute renal failure
Microangiopathic haemolytic anaemia
Non-immune mediated thrombocytopenia
Approximately what percentage of patients with haemolytic uraemic syndrome will require dialysis?
Describe the mechanism by which red blood cells are destroyed in haemolytic uraemic syndrome.
Microangiopathic haemolytic anaemia is caused by non-immune red blood cell destruction due to shearing of red blood cells through platelet microthrombi
Programmed cell death receptor 1 (PD-1) is found on what cell type?
What is the effect of PD-1 binding to its ligand PD-L1 on activated tumour cells?
T cell is unable to produce an effective immune response (selective immunosuppression)
Describe the mechanism of action of nivolumab.
Inhibits the programmed cell death (PD-1) receptor from binding to its ligands (PD-L1 and PD-L2) on tumour cells, reactivating cytotoxic T lymphocytes and anti-tumour immunity.
Describe the mechanism of action of pembrolizumab.
Inhibits the programmed cell death 1 (PD-1) receptor from binding to its ligands (PD‑L1 and PD‑L2) on tumour cells, reactivating cytotoxic T lymphocytes and anti-tumour immunity.
Name 4 precautions for the use of pembrolizumab.

Significant autoimmune disease
Organ transplantation
Previous history of viral hepatitis
HIV/AIDS
Describe the mechanism of action of ipilimumab.
Antibody that binds to the cytotoxic T lymphocyte-associated antigen 4 (CTLA-4) resulting in an enhanced T-cell mediated immune response which leads to tumour cell death.
Name the most common manifestation of immune-related adverse events associated with checkpoint inhibitors.
Describe the clinical manifestations of dermatologic toxicity due to immune-related adverse effects associated with checkpoint inhibitors.

Reticular, maculopapular, faintly erythematous rash on the trunk or extremitites.
Vitiligo
Steven-Johnson syndrome/TENS
Which organ system is involved first in immune-related adverse effects related to checkpoint inhibitor therapy?
Among checkpoint inhibitors, which type of agent is more likely to result in immune-related adverse effects: cytotoxic T-lymphocyte associated antigen or PD-1 inhibitors?
CTLA-4 inhibitors are more likely to have immune-related adverse effects
Describe the gastrointestinal manifestations seen in patients with checkpoint inhibitors (PD-1 or CTLA inhibitors).

Diarrhoea
Colitis (abdominal pain, radiographic/colonoscpic evidence of colonic inflammation)
Describe the management of a patient with grade 1 diarrhoea (less than 4 stools per day over baseline) due to PD-1 inhibitor.

Continue treatment with PD-1 inhibitor
Symptomatic treatment (fluid replacement, loperamide)
Describe management of grade 3 (≥ 7 stools per day over baseline or severe abdominal pain/peritoneal signs) gastrointestinal immune-related adverse events due to PD-1 inhibitors.

Withhold PD-1 inhibitor
Evaluate for perforation or peritonitis
Fluid replacement
IV methylprednisolone (if no perforation)
Disease response to treatment with checkpoint inhibitors differs from cytotoxic chemotherapy in what way?
Patients treated with checkpoint inhibitors may have transient worsening of disease (progression of known lesions, appearance of new lesions) before the disease stabilises or tumour regresses.
Name the most common cause of primary hyperaldosteronism.
Name 2 common causes of primary hyperaldosteronism.

Aldosterone-producing adenomas (30-40%)
Bilateral idiopathic hyperaldosteronism (bilateral adrenal hyperplasia) 60-70%
In primary hyperaldosteronism, what would be the expected concentration of plasma renin?
Very low plasma renin concentration/plasma renin activity.
Describe the 2 underlying broad mechanisms of hyperthyroidism.

Increased de novo synthesis of thyroid hormone (increased radioiodine uptake)
Inflammation/destruction of thyroid tissue with release of preformed thyroid hormone into circulation (near absent radioiodine uptake)
Name 3 causes of hyperthyroidism which will have increased radioiodine uptake.
Name 3 ultrashort acting preparations of insulin.
Name 2 commonly used long acting insulin preparations.
What was the clinical question asked in The Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT)?
In patients with T1DM, how does strict glycemic control with intensive therapy compare with conventional therapy in preventing microvascular complications?
Name 3 causes of hyperthyroidism with a near absent radioiodine uptake.

Thyroiditis
Exogenous thyroid hormone
Ectopic production of thyroid hormone
In non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy, visual loss is primarily due to?
Describe the findings and diagnosis seen in the color fundus image below:

Non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy:
Retinal haemorrhages
Yellow lipid exudates
Dull white cotton wool spots (nerve fiber layer infarcts)
Describe the findings and diagnosis in the color fundus image below:
Proliferative diabetic retinopathy displaying prominent neovascularisation at the disc.
Name the 2 major forms of diabetic retinopathy.
Describe the typical characteristics of proliferative diabetic retinopathy.
Proliferative diabetic retinopathy is marked by the presence of neovascularisation arising from the disc and/or retinal vessels.
Describe the mechanisms by which permanent loss of vision can occur in proliferative retinopathy.
What is the recommended frequency for diabetic retinopathy screening in patients with diabetes?
Every 2 years unless there are additional risk factors (poor diabetic control, hypertension, hyperlipidaemia, renal disease, long duration of diabetes), in which cause it should be annually.
What is the strongest predictor of diabetic retinopathy?
Name the 2 most important interventions in preventing diabetic retinopathy.

Good glycaemic control (HbA1C ≤7%)
Good blood pressure control
What type of diabetes mellitus is more likely to develop diabetic retinopathy?
Name the firstline treatment for high risk and severe proliferative diabetic retinopathy.
Panretinal laser photocoagulation (Diabetic Retinopathy Study demonstrated 50% reduction in severe vision loss)
What is the preferred treatment for patients with macula oedema due to non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy?
Intravitreal VEGF inhibitors as initial therapy (pegaptinib)
What was the bottom line of the Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT)?
Among patients with T1DM, strict glycemic control prevents up to 70% of microvascular complications, particularly retinopathy.
What was the clinical question studied in the Epidemiology of Diabetes Interventions and Complications cohort study?
In patients with T1DM, what is the benefit of intensive therapy in reducing the long-term incidence of a CV event?
What is the bottom line of the Epidemiology of Diabetes Interventions and Complications (EDIC) cohort study?

The EDIC long term follow-up to the DCCT demonstrated that a period of intensive glycemic control reduced the subsequent risk of a CV event by 42% and severe CV events by 57% at 11 years among patients with T1DM.
What was the clinical question studied in the Scandinavian Simvastatin Survival Study (4S)?
Among patients with prior MI or angina with hyperlipidemia, does addition of simvastatin reduce all-cause mortality when compared to placebo?
What was the bottom line in the Scandinavian Simvastatin Survival Study (4S)?
In patients with prior MI or angina and hyperlipidemia, Simvastatin reduces all-cause mortality as well as CAD-related mortality.
Name 2 statins that have less intrinsic muscle toxicity compared to other statins.
In a patient taking high dose methotrexate, what is the preferred antibiotic prophylaxis for Pneumocystis jirovecii?
Dapsone. Trimethoprim + sulfamethoxazole should be avoided because there is an increased risk of methotrexate toxicity.
Name 2 important stimuli which increase secrection of aldosterone from the zona glomerulosa of the adrenal cortex.

Increased extracellular potassium
Increased angiotensin II levels
Describe the renal effects of aldosterone secretion.

Increased sodium reabsorption (and therefore water via osmosis)
Increased secretion of potassium
Increased secretion of hydrogen ions
How does aldosterone increase sodium absorption

The primary effect of aldosterone is to increase the number of open sodium channels in the luminal membrane of the principal cells in the cortical collecting tubule, leading to increased sodium reabsorption. The ensuing loss of cationic sodium makes the lumen electronegative, thereby creating an electrical gradient that favors the secretion of cellular potassium into the lumen through potassium channels in the luminal membrane.
What is the triad of primary hyperaldosteronism?
Name the initial investigations (case detection) for suspected primary hyperaldosteronism.
Name 2 methods used to confirm a diagnosis of primary hyperaldosteronism.
Describe how a saline infusion test is performed to confirm the diagnosis of primary hyperaldosteronism.

Infusion of 2 litres of isotonic saline over 4 hours with the patient seated. In a patient with primary hyperaldosteronism, plasma aldosterone concentration will not be suppressed (values will be above 277 pmol/L).
Name the initial investigation which should be used to determine the subtype of primary hyperaldosteronism (e.g. adenoma, bilateral hyperplasia or carcinoma).
Name the most accurate method for differentiating between unilateral aldosterone producing adenoma and bilateral adrenal hyperplasia in patients with primary hyperaldosteronism.
Adrenal vein sampling (performed when an adrenal CT is normal, shows bilateral abnormalities or shows a unilateral abnormality but the patient is over the age of 35 years)
When is adrenal vein sampling indicated in patients with confirmed primary hyperaldosteronism?
If there no tumour detected on adrenal CT or if it demonstrates a unilateral abnormality but the patient is over 35 years.
Name 5 scenarios when you should consider testing for primary hyperaldosteronism.

Hypertension with hypokalaemia
Severe hypertension
Drug-resistant hypertension
Hypertension with adrenal incidentaloma
Onset of hypertension less than 20 years of age
Describe the clinical features of inclusion body myositis.

Progressive weakness of proximal leg and arm muscle groups
Myalgias (mild) accompany the weakness
Deep tendon reflexes decrease in parallel with the decline in strength
Dysphagia due to cricopharyngeal muscle involvement (one-third to 50%)
Name the most common initial presentation of inclusion body myositis.
Proximal leg weakness (difficulty getting up out of a chair or frequent falls)
Name the 2 clinical hallmarks of inclusion body myositis on examination.

Quadriceps (knee extensor) muscle weakness and wasting
Forearm flexor (wrist, finger flexor) muscle weakness and wasting
What is usually the earliest examination finding in patients with inclusion body myositis?
Weakness on distal finger flexion (at the DIP joint)
Describe how inclusion body myositis clinical features differ from polymyositis and dermatomyositis.
More likely to have asymmetric and distal muscle involvement.
Name 3 muscle biopsy findings that are highly specific for inclusion body myositis.

Rimmed vacuoles
Mononuclear cell inflammatory infiltrate of non-necrotic muscle fibres
Amyloid deposits or tubulofilaments by electron microscopy
What are the expected creatine kinase levels in patients with inclusion body myositis?
May be normal, or up to 10 times the upper limit of normal. More than 20 times the upper limit of normal suggests an alternate diagnosis.
What is the mean age at diagnosis for inclusion body myositis?

Describe how excess iron is excreted.
There is no physiologic mechanism to excrete excess iron once it has been absorbed into the body.
What is the role of transferrin?
Major transporter for iron trafficking through the plasma.
Name 2 common conditions in which transferrin saturation is reduced.

Iron deficiency anaemia
Anaemia of chronic disease
Name the cellular storage protein for iron.
Name the protein which functions as a major exporter of iron (eg. from enterocytes into the circulation).

Transports iron from mother to foetus
Transfers absorbed iron from enterocytes into the circulation
Allows macrophages to recycle iron from damaged/senescent red cells back into the circulation
Name the protein which facilitates transport of iron across the enterocyte's cell membrane into the cell.
Hepcidin binds to ferroportin and induces its internalisation and lysosomal degradation.

Reduces iron absorption in the intestine
Reduces release of iron from macrophages
In iron overload, what is the expected concentration (low or high) of hepcidin?

Hepcidin production from the liver will be high. Hepcidin acts by inhibiting ferroportin, in turn blocking iron absorption through enterocytes and preventing release of iron from macrophages into the circulation.
Name 5 factors which result in downregulation of hepcidin.
Name the most common missense mutation in the HFE gene resulting in hereditary haemochromatosis.
Describe the pattern of inheritence for hereditary haemochromatosis.
Clinical manifestations of iron overload typically occur after what age?
Age 40 in males (later in females) due to progressive accumulation over many years.
Describe the pathophysiology of iron overload in herediatry haemochromatosis.
Increased iron absorption of both haem and non-haem iron leading to progressive iron accumulation (no normal mechanism for excretion of excess iron once it has been absorbed).
Name 4 organs which are particularly prone to iron deposition in hereditary haemochromatosis.
Roughly what percentage of patients who are homozygous for C282Y develop iron overload?
Name 3 bacterial infections for which patients with iron overload are at increased risk.
Name the most sensitive initial screening test for hereditary haemochromatosis.
Name the most commonly affected joint in acute calcium pyrophosphate crystal arthritis (pseudogout).
Knee is affected in over 50% of cases
Name 2 investigations performed in the diagnostic evaluation of a patient with suspected calcium pyrophosphate deposition disease (CPPD).

Arthrocentesis and synovial fluid analysis of affected joint
X-ray of affected joint
Describe the findings and diagnosis shown in the image below:

Faintly yellow, positively birefringent, rhomboidal, intracellular crystal characteristic of calcium pyrophosphate dihydrate (CPP) is seen in the synovial fluid of a patient with acute CPP crystal arthritis (pseudogout) when viewed with compensated, polarized microscopy.
What is the most salient finding on synovial fluid analysis in patients with acute calcium pyrophosphate crystal arthritis (pseudogout)?
Positively birefringent CPP crystals by compensated polarized light microscopy.
Is a formal examination by a dentist required before starting antiresorptive therapy for osteoporosis?
No, only an assessment of dental hygiene is recommended.
What type of surgery is a major risk factor for medication related osteonecrosis of the jaw?
Should antiresorptive therapy be withheld before a planned dental extraction?
No evidence that this decreases the risk of medication related osteonecrosis of the jaw. It is not recommended to stop bisphosphonate therapy before a planned dental extraction.

Leukopenia (reversible)

Name the most common side effect of metronidazole.

Promote assembly of tubulin into stable non-functional microtubules, and inhibit disassembly, arresting cell cycles in late G2 and M phase.

Isoniazid 300mg daily for 6 months
Rifampicin 600mg daily for 6 months
Ethambutol 15mg/kg up to 1200mg orally, daily for 2 months
Pyrazinamide 40mg/kg up to 2g daily for 2 months
Describe the 4 criteria which must be met in order to be eligible for standard short-course therapy for active tuberculosis.

Organism is not drug resistant
Patient able to comply with treatment
No evidence of miliary (disseminated) or central nervous system TB
Extensive cavitation is not present on the initial chest x-ray
What should be administered with isoniazid to reduce the risk of peripheral neuropathy?
Name the 2 tests used to demonstrate previous tuberculosis exposure.

Positive tuberculin skin test (Mantoux)
TB-specific interferon gamma release assay (IGRA)
Name 2 patient populations who should be screened for potential latent tuberculosis.

Recent contact exposure to tuberculosis (particularly within the last 2 years)
Increased risk of reactivation of latent tuberculosis (e.g. planned renal transplant)
A patient with drug-susceptible active tuberculosis has been commenced on standard short-course daily regimen. How long until he can be considered non-infectious?
What is the action of tazobactam?
Inhibits the action of beta-lactamase, which extends the spectrum of activity of piperacillin with tazobactam to cover many beta-lactamase-producing organisms.
Describe 4 clinical features of optic neuritis.

Eye pain which is often worse with eye movement (92%)
Significant decrease in visual acuity (90%)
Afferent pupillary defect always occurs if the other eye is uninvolved and otherwise healthy
Usually monocular
Name the most common pathologic basis for optic neuritis.
Inflammatory demyelination of the optic nerve
What is the typical visual field defect seen in optic neuritis?
Optic neuritis preferentially affects what gender?
Two thirds of cases occur in women
Give a definition for optic neuritis.
Inflammatory, demyelinating condition that causes acute, urually monocular, visual loss.
What is the clinical hallmark of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis?
Combination of upper and lower motor neuron signs and symptoms.

What is the other name of idiopathic intracranial hypertension?
What is the classic demographic affected by idiopathic intracranial hypertension?
Name 5 common symptoms seen in idiopathic intracranial hypertension (pseudotumour cerebri).

Headache (84 - 92%)
Transient visual obscuration (68 - 72%)
Intracranial noises (pulsatile tinnitus) (52 - 60%)
Photopsia (48 - 54%)
Back pain (53%)
Name the most common presenting symptom of idiopathic intracranial hypertension.
How do you calculate anion gap?
Give a definition for drug resistant tuberculosis.
Tuberculosis caused by an isolate of Mycobacterium tuberculosis that is resistant to one of the first-line anti-TB drugs (isoniazid, rifampicin, pyrazinamide, ethambutol or streptomycin.
Give a definition for multi-drug resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB).
Mycobacterium tuberculosis that is resistant to at least isoniazid and rifampicin and possibly additional agents
Give a definition for extensively drug-resistant tuberculosis.
Mycobacterium tuberculosis that is resistant to isoniazid and rifampicin and to at least one quinolone and one injectable agent (amikacin, kanamycin, or capreomycin)
Name the single greatest risk factor for the presence of multi-drug resistant tuberculosis.
History of prior treatment (especially if incomplete or unsupervised)
Approximately what percentage of individuals infected with Mycobacterium tuberculosis develop active disease.
Name the test used for nucleic acid amplification testing of sputum for Mycobacterium complex DNA and molecular detection of resistance to rifampicin.
Name the 2 genetic mutations which account for 90% of Mycobacterium tuberculosis isoniazid resistance.
Name 3 examinations which should be performed in a patient prior to commencing antituberculosis therapy.
Name the genetic mutation which results in Mycobacterium tuberculosis resistance to rifampicin.
Describe the mechanism of action of isoniazid.

May involve inhibiting synthesis of mycolic acids, constituents of the mycobacterial cell wall. It is bactericidal against actively dividing M. tuberculosis and bacteriostatic against resting bacteria; it is active against intra‑ and extracellular organisms.
Describe the mechanism of action of rifampicin.
Inhibit bacterial RNA polymerase; rifampicin and rifabutin are bactericidal against rapidly dividing M. tuberculosis and active against those which are semi-dormant (intracellular organisms).
Name the genetic mutation which results in Mycobacterium tuberculosis resistance to pyrazinamide.
Mutations in the pncA gene which encodes the enzyme pyrazinamidase (converts pyrazinamide from its prodrug from to active form, pyrazinoic acid).
Name the 3 most common examination findings seen in idiopathic intracranial hypertension.
Name 3 investigations which should be performed in a patient with suspected idiopathic intracranial hypertension.

MRI venography is the preferred neuroimaging test
Lumbar puncture (for opening pressure > 20cmH20, will have normal biochemistry in IIH)
Ophthalmologic evaluation (visual field examination, optic nerve photographs)
MR venography is the preferred neuroimaging investigation in patients with suspected idiopathic intracranial hypertension to exclude what differential diagnosis?
Name the dipeptidyl peptidase-4 inhibitor that does not require dose adjustment in renal failure.
Linagliptin is mostly excreted unchanged in the bile and does not require dose adjustment.
Describe the mechanism of action of dipeptidyl peptidase-4 inhibitors.

Inhibit dipeptidyl peptidase-4 (DPP-4) thereby increasing the concentration of the incretin hormones glucagon-like peptide-1 and glucose-dependent insulinotropic polypeptide; glucose-dependent insulin secretion is increased and glucagon production reduced.
Describe the mechanism of action of linezolid.
Inhibits bacterial protein synthesis by binding to the 50S ribosomal subunit and preventing formation of a functional 70S complex.
Name the 2 serious side effects which limit the use of linezolid for prolonged courses.

Myelosuppression
Mitochondrial effects (optic and peripheral neuropathy, lactic acidosis)
Prolonged treatment with linezolid can cause optic and peripheral neuropathy. What is the underlying mechanism of these side effects?
Acute osteomyelitis is defined as symptoms for duration less than?
Describe empirical therapy for vertebral osteomyelitis in adults.
Ceftriaxone 2g IV daily PLUS vancomycin IV
Pyridoxine should be administered with what anti-tuberculous drug to reduce the risk of peripheral neuropathy?
Where is Von Willebrand factor made (2)?
Name the most common inherited bleeding disorder.
Describe the role of von Willebrand factor in haemostasis.

Binding to both platelets and endothelial components, forming an adhesive bridge between platelets and vascular subendothelial structures at sites of endothelial injury and between adjacent platelets in areas with high shear.
Von Willebrand factor contributes to fibrin clot formation by acting as a carrier protein for what clotting factor?
The half-life of clotting factor VIII is significantly reduced if it is not bound to a carrier protein called?
Risk in exposed divided by risk in  unexposed
Describe how atrial flutter is classified electrophysiologically.

Typical (macroreentrant circuit traversing the cavo-tricuspid isthmus)
Atypical (does not involve cavo-tricuspid isthmus)
What factor is used to distinguish between typical and atypical atrial flutter?
Typical atrial flutter is also known as?
What is the usual direction of the circuit in typical atrial flutter?
Flutter waves in typical counter clockwise (CTI-dependent) atrial flutter are best seen in what leads?
Negative flutter waves seen in inferior leads (II, III, aVF)
Describe how patients with von Willebrand disease typically present.

Easy bruising
Skin bleeding
Prolonged bleeding from mucosal surfaces (e.g. oropharyngeal, gastrointestinal, uterine)
Ulcerative colitis usually involves what part of the colon?
Inflammation in ulcerative colitis is limited to what layer of the colon?
Describe the recommended initial therapy for active proctitis or distal colitis in patients with ulcerative colitis.
Rectal mesalazine preparation PLUS oral 5-aminosalicylate preparation
In a patient with acute proctitis who is failing to improve on the combination of rectal mesalazine and oral 5-aminosalicylate, what treatment should be added?
Describe the management of unresponsive active proctitis or distal colitis.
Prednisolone 40 to 50 mg orally, once daily in the morning until clinical response, then taper over 6 to 8 weeks to cease.
Name the most common extra-intestinal manifestation of inflammatory bowel disease.
What antibodies should be tested in evaluating patients for inflammatory bowel disease?
Antibody testing is not part of the diagnostic evaluation of patients with suspected inflammatory bowel disease.
Acute severe ulcerative colitis is defined according to the Truelove and Witts criteria. What are these 5 criteria?

6 or more bloody stools/day
Temperature > 37.8°C
Heart rate > 90 beats/minute
Haemoglobin less than 105g/L
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate more than 30mm/hour
Describe the initial therapy for patients with acute severe ulcerative colitis.
Name 3 drug classes that should be avoided in patients with severe ulcerative colitis.
Describe salvage therapy for patients with acute severe ulcerative colitis who have failed to respond depiste 3 - 5 days of intravenous corticosteroid treatment.
Cyclosporin 2mg/kg daily OR infliximab 5mg/kg over 2 hours at week 0, 2 and 6
Only try one of the above, if no success, consider colectomy (per Dunedin course)
What is the role of corticosteroids as maintenance therapy to prevent relapse of ulcerative colitis?
Should not be used as they are no more effective than placebo and are associated with serious long-term adverse effects.

Adjacent corona radiata

Bilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation below the level of the lesion (spinothalamic tracts)
Bowel/bladder/sexual dysfunction depending upon level of the lesion

Tactile, position/proprioception and vibratory sensation are normal (dorsal columns not involved)

What is the name of the spinal cord syndrome shown in the image below:

Involves the dorsal column, corticostpinal tract, and spinothalamic tract unilaterally.

Dorsal columns
Corticospinal tracts
Descending central autonomic tracts to bladder control centres in the sacral cord

Paraesthesias (dorsal column)
Weakness
Extensor plantar responses

Thyroid-stimulating hormone receptor is also called?

There is no increase in free T4 and T3. There is increase in serum total T4 and T3 concentrations (there is increased concentration of both serum thyroid binding globulin and thyroid hormones).

Germline mutation in the phosphatase and tensin homolog (PTEN) gene
Hamartomatous tumours of the outer root sheath of the hair follicle (benign)

Acral keratoses
