Name the most common chest x-ray finding in patients with tuberculosis.
Tests for latent tuberculosis rely on what?
Immune sensitisation (type IV or delayed-type hypersensitivity) to mycobacterial protein antigens that might occur following exposure to (and infection by) mycobacteria.
Name the most important risk factor for progression to active tuberculosis in patients with latent tuberculosis infection.
Name 6 risk factors for the development of active tuberculosis among persons infected with Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

Acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS)
Human immunodeficiency syndrome (HIV)
Transplantation (related to immunosuppressants)
Silicosis
Chronic renal failure requiring haemodialysis
Recent Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection (< 2 years)
In patients exposed to Mycobacterium tuberculosis, the greatest risk of developing active tuberculosis is within what time frame?
Within 2 years from date of exposure
Describe 5 situations in which treatment for latent tuberculosis infection should be considered.

HIV infection
Recent tuberculin converters
Close contacts of a patient with smear-positive pulmonary tuberculosis
Immunocompromised patients/receiving immunosuppressive drugs
Patients younger than 35 years with no known tuberculosis contact
Single drug treatment can be used for latent tuberculosis because of the small number of organisms involved. What is the first line drug?
Describe the mechanism of action of ethambutol.
May inhibit incorporation of mycolic acid into the mycobacterial cell wall. It is slowly bacteriostatic against M. tuberculosis.
Optic neuritis is a common side effect of what antimycobacterial drug?
Name the most sensitive tool for the detection of Mycobacterium tuberculosis.
Describe the mechanism of action of eculizumab.

Eculizumab is a humanized monoclonal IgG antibody that binds to complement protein C5, preventing cleavage into C5a and C5b. Blocking the formation of C5b inhibits the subsequent formation of terminal complex C5b-9 or MAC.
Drug resistant or refractory cytomegalovirus infection is usually treated with what drug?
Which drug should be used if a UL97 mutation is identified in a patient with cytomegalovirus?
Name 4 mycoplasma species which can cause pathology in humans
Describe the mechanism of action of daptomycin.

This cyclic lipopeptide inserts into Gram-positive bacterial cytoplasmic membranes in the presence of calcium, causing depolarisation, potassium efflux (impairing potassium-dependent DNA, RNA and protein synthesis) and cell death.
What other drug should be avoided while taking daptomycin?
Statin therapy (may increase risk of myopathy)
What complication of daptomycin treatment may affect the lungs?
Daptomycin is only active against {{c1::Gram-positive}} bacteria.
Describe the mechanism of action of heparin.
Inactivate clotting factors IIa (thrombin) and Xa by binding to antithrombin III; LMWHs and danaparoid have a much greater effect on factor Xa than on thrombin.
Describe first-line secondary antibiotic prophylaxis to prevent subsequent episodes of spontaneous bacterial peritonitis in patients with ascities due to cirrhosis.
Primary prophylaxis for spontaneous bacterial peritonitis is controversial. Describe the criteria for patients in whom primary antibiotic prophylaxis may be appropriate.

Patients who have ascities and ascitic fluid protein concentration less than 15g/L and either impaired renal function (creatinine > 110mmol/L) or liver failure (Child-Pugh score 9 or more and serum bilirubin 50 or more)

What is secondary antibiotic prophylaxis for spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (in patients with ascites due to cirrhosis) in whom trimethoprim+sulfamethoxazole is contraindicated or has previously failed?
Antibiotic prophylaxis is recommended for all patients who have cirrhosis with upper gastrointestinal bleeding. What is the preferred antibiotic prophyalxis?

Norfloxacin 12 hourly for 2 days if tolerating oral intake
Ceftriaxone 1g IV daily for 2 days where oral therapy is not possible

The two goals of the complement system are opsonization (deposition of C3b on a target) and promotion of an inflammatory response. The inflammatory response is primarily mediated by liberation of what 2 anaphylatoxins?
What is the primary goal of the complement system?
Destruction of microbes (through opsonization and promotion of an inflammatory response)
Complement found in the plasma is predominantly synthesized by what organ?
Opsonization is accomplished by coating target microbes with larget quantities of?
Describe 2 ways in which the complement pathway facilitates destruction of microbes.
QuantiFERON-TB Gold assay is a test used to diagnose latent tuberculosis. What does it measure?
T-cell release of interferon-gamma following stimulation by antigens unique to Mycobacterium tuberculosis.
Name the 2 Mycobacterium tuberculosis-specific antigens used in the interferon-gamma release assays to diagnose latent tuberculosis.

What is the sensitivity of QuantiFERON-TB Gold In-Tube test for latent tuberculosis?
What is the specificity of interferon gamma release assays for the diagnosis of latent tuberculosis?
Are interferon-gammae release assays (IGRA) useful in the diagnosis of active Mycobacterium tuberculosis?
No, IGRAs cannot distinguish between latent infection and active tuberculosis, and should not be used for diagnosis of active tuberculosis.
Does a negatie tuberculosis-specific interferon-gamma release assay (IGRA) exclude active tuberculosis?
What is the effect of HIV infection on tuberculosis-specific interferon-gamma release assays (IGRA)?
IGRA sensitivity is diminished by HIV infection (lower CD4 counts have been associated with higher rates of indeterminate IGRA results).
Describe how a diagnosis of latent tuberculosis is made.

Demonstration of prior tuberculosis infection (interferon-gama release assays or tuberculin skin test)
Excluding active tuberculosis
Name the major constituent of the cell envelope of Mycobacterium tuberculosis.
A slow growth rate is a distinguishing feature of Mycobacterium tuberculosis. How long may it take for detectable growth on culture?
Name 3 factors which are important for controlling replication of Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

Flattening of the posterior sclera
Distension of the perioptic subarachnoid space
Enhancement of the prelaminar optic nerve
Empty sella
Vertical tortuosity of the orbital optic nerve
Name the most common cause of an anterior mediastinal mass in multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1.

MEN1 is present in 20 - 60% of patients with Zollinger-Ellison syndrome.
Ctrptococcosis is an invasive function finection due to what 2 organisms?
Ctryptococcal infection typically begins in what organ?
What is the most frequently encountered manifestation of ctryptococcosis in patients with advanced immunosuppression?
The vast majority of cryptococcal meningoencephalitis are seen among patients with AIDS and a CD4 cell count less than?
Early detection of cryptococcosis can made up to 3 weeks prior to the onset of neurologic symptoms using what investigation?

Indolent onset over a period of 1 - 2 weeks
Fever
Malaise
Headache
Confusion/lethargy
Skin rash resembling molluscum contagiosum
Onset of symptoms in Cryptococcus neoformans meningoencephalitis is typically over what time period?
Describe the examination findings which may be seen in meningoencphalitis due to Cryptococcus neoformans.

Lethargy or confusion
Focal neurologic deficits such as cranial neuropathies
Skin rash resembling molluscum contagiosum

Binds irreversibly to ergosterol in fungal cell membranes causing cell death by altering their permeability and allowing leakage of intracellular components.
Describe 4 renal adverse effects of aphotericin B.

Acute kidney injury (renal vasoconstriction)
Urinary potassium wasting and hypokalaemia
Metabolic acidosis due to distal/type 1 renal tubular acidosis
Polyuria due to nephrogenic diabetes insipidus
Cryptococcus meningitis in immunocompetent patients is usually caused by what organism?
Cryptococcal meningitis in HIV-infected adults is usually caused by what organism?
Describe induction therapy for treatment of HIV-infected patients with cryptococcal meningitis.

Amphotericin B desoxycholate (can use liposomal or lipid complex)
PLUS
Flucytosine
Describe consolidation therapy for HIV-infected patients with cryptococcal meningitis.
Fluconazole 800mg orally for the first dose, then 400mg daily for 8 weeks
Describe maintenance therapy for HIV-infected patients with cryptococcal meningitis.
Describe 5 findings on lumbar puncture in a HIV-infected patient with cryptococcus meningitis.

Low white blood cell count in the CSF
Mononuclear predominance
Protein may be slightly elevated
Glucose concentrations are commonly low
Lumbar puncture is normal in 25 - 30% of patients.

Cryptococcal culture (3 - 7 days)
India ink staining
Cryptococcal antigen
Name 3 predictors of poor prognosis in HIV-infected patients with cryptococcal meningitis.

Abnormal mental status
Cerebrospinal fluid antigen titer > 1:1024 (high burden of yeasts)
CSF whie blood cell count < 20/microL (poor host response)
Name the stain which can be performed on cerebrospinal fluid to provide an early diagnosis of cryptococcal meningitis.
Describe the diagnostic evaluation of a HIV-infected patient with suspected cryptococcal meningitis.

Serum cryptococcal antigen
Neuroimaging if raised intracranial pressure or mass lesion is suspected
Lumbar puncutre (culture, India ink stain, cryptococcal antigen)

There is no role for empiric corticosteroids during induction therapy. Worse neurologic outcome, slower rates of fungal CSF clearance, higher adverse event rates.
Name a class of antifungal drugs which have no activity against Cryptococcus neoformans.
What is the duration of induction therapy for HIV-infected patients with cryptococcal meningitis?
When should antiretroviral therapy be commenced in HIV-infected patients with cryptococcal meningoencephalitis?
2 - 10 weeks after antifungal therapy has been initiated.
Due to risk of immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome (IRIS)

Fever, chills, hypotension, nausea, vomiting, headache.
Describe the mechanism of action of echinocandins.

Inhibit 1,3-beta-D-glucan synthase, inhibiting synthesis of 1,3-beta-D-glucan in the fungal cell wall, which alters cell membrane permeability. Fungicidal against Candida spp. and fungistatic against Aspergillus spp.
Name 2 key fungal species against which echinocandins have activity.
Describe the mechanism of action of benzodiazepines.
Benzodiazepines potentiate the inhibitory effects of GABA throughout the CNS, resulting in anxiolytic, sedative, hypnotic, muscle relaxant and antiepileptic effects.
Describe the mechanism of action of dipyridamole.
Inhibits platelet function by inhibiting phosphodiesterase, which increases platelet cAMP; also inhibits endogenous adenosine reuptake causing coronary vasodilation.
Name 3 tumours which are associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia 2A.
Medullary thyroid cancer is a neuroendocrine tumour of what cell type?
Parafollicular or C cells of the thyroid gland

Farmer's lung (a type of hypersensitivity pneumonitis) is caused by what types of organism?

Immune-mediated condition that occurs in response to inhaled antigens that are small enough to deposit in the distal airways and alveoli. TH1 inflammatory pattern with emerging evidence of TH17 subsets involved.
What is the characteristic finding on bronchoscopy with bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) in patients with hypersensitivity pneumonitis?
Name the 2 most common autoantigens to which ANCA is directed against in granolumatosis with polyangiitis.

Proteinase 3 (PR3) which is observed in 80 - 90% of patients.

Granulomatosis with polyangiitis

Tricuspid stenosis results in cannon a waves on the right atrial waveform.

Tricuspid regurgitation classically produces tall v waves on the right atrial waveform.

Right atrial pressure tracing shows prominent v waves in a patient with tricuspid regurgitation due to blood being regurgitated back into the right atrium during ventricular systole.

Describe 5 major changes in cardiovascular physiology during pregnancy.

Increased cardiac output
Expanded blood volume (equates to increased preload)
Reduced systemic vascular resistance (reduced afterload)
Reduced blood pressure
Increased heart rate

Remains unchanged from normal non-pregnant values.

Expanded plasma volume (in excess of the increase in red blood cell mass) and resultant physiologic anaemia
Mild neutrophilia
Mild thrombocytopenia
Increased procoagulant factors and decreased natural anticoagulants
Diminished fibrinolysis

Decreased protein S

Acute rheumatic fever and rheumatic heart disease are highly prevalent in what communities in Australia?
Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities
Acute rheumatic fever is a non-suppurative sequela that occurs several weeks following infection with what organism?
Acute rheumatic fever is a clinical diagnosis which is made using what clinical criteria?
What are the 5 major manifestations of acute rheumatic fever used in the Jones Criteria?

Carditis and valvulitis (e.g. Pancarditis) 50 - 70%
Arthritis (usually migratory polyarthritis predominantly involving the large joints (35 - 66%)
Central nervous system involvement (e.g. Sydenham chorea) 10 - 30%
Subcutaneous nodules 0 - 10%
Erythema marginatum <6%
What are the 4 minor manifestations of acute rheumatic fever used in the Jones Criteria?

Fever
Arthralgia
Elevated acute phase reactants (ESR or CRP)
Prolonged PR interval on ECG
What is usually the earliest symptomatic manifestation of acute rheumatic fever?
Arthritis which usually presents within 21 days of Group A Streptococcus infection
Patients with arthritis due to acute rheumatic fever often have rapid resolution of the arthritis in response to what drug class?
Alters natural history of arthritis: causes arthritis to subside quickly in the joint(s) affected and does not "migrate" to new joints.
Describe the arthritis seen in acute rheumatic fever (4).

Polyarthritis
"Migratory"
No long-term joint deformity
Pain is typically more prominent than objective signs of inflammation
What is the Carey Coombs murmur?

A short mid-diastolic murmur hear loudest at the apex. Is an indicator of moerate-severe mitral regurgitation as a result of increased blood flow across the mitral valve during left ventricular filling.

Permanent heart valve damage following acute rheumatic fever.
Acute rehumatic fever affects what structurs in the heart?
Pancarditis: pericardium, epicardium, myocardium, and endocardium (valvulitits)
What is the most prominent manifestation of rheumatic carditis?
Valvulitis (particularly affecting the mitral and aortic valves).
Describe the auscultation findings seen in mitral regurgitation.
Name the most commonly affected valve in rheumatic heart disease.
Mitral valve is involved in nearly all cases of rheumatic heart disease.
Aortic valve is involved in approximately 20 - 30% of cases.
Rheumatic carditis in acute rheumatic fever typically occurs how long after Group A Strococcus pharyngitis?
Young patients (under 30 years) with rheumatic heart disease are most likely to present with what valvular lesion?
Patients with rheumatic heart disease who are over the age of 30 years are most likely to present with what valvular lesion?
In rheumatic carditis due to acute rheumatic fever, what is the most common early valvular manifestation?
May be accompanied by aortic regurgitation an/or uncommonly by tricuspid regurgitation.
Name the 2 most commonly affected valves in rheumatic carditis due to acute rheumatic fever.
Sydenham chorea typically presents how long after infection with Group A Streptococcus?
How is muscle weakness due to Sydenham chorea best demonstrated on physical examination?
Asking the patient to squeeze the examiner's hands: pressure of the patient's grip increases and decreases capriciously.
Called relapsing grip or "milk maid's sign."

Abrupt non-rhythmic, involuntary movements
Muscular weakness
Emotional disturbances (outbursts of inappropriate crying and restlessness)
Usually worse on one side
Ceases during sleep

Head is often involved, with erratic movements of the face that resemble grimaces, grins and frowns. Tongue, if affected, can resemble a "bag of worms" when protruded, and protrusion cannot be maintained.
Describe 2 skin lesions seen in acute rheumatic fever.

Erythema marginatum (pink/faintly red, non-pruritic rash involving the trunk but spares the face)
Subcutaneous nodules (firm, painless, often multiple)
Subcutaneous nodules in acute rheumatic fever most commonly affect what area?
Nodules are usually located over a bony surface or prominence or near tendons (usually extensor surfaces) and usually symmetric.
Name the most common and severe sequela of acute rheumatic fever.
Describe the findings and diagnosis shown in the image below:

Ulnar deviation, metacarpophalangeal subluxation, and swan-neck deformities.
X-ray demonstrates no true joint space narrowing or erosion.
Name 2 diseases which can cause Jaccoud arthropathy.

Systemic lupus erytheamtosus
Acute rheumatic heart disease (late sequela)
To demonstrate preceding group A Streptococcus infection, what is the most helfpul test in patients with suspected acute rheumatic fever?
Rapid streptococcal antigen test is often negative. Culture or detection of the organism is usually no longer possible by the time acute rheumatic fever presents.
Name 5 tests used in the diagnostic evaluation of a patient with suspected acute rheumatic fever.

Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR)
C-reactive protein (CRP)
Electrocardiogram (ECG)
Elevated or rising antistreptococcal antibody titer (either antistreptolysin O or antideoxyribonuclease B)
Echocardiogram
Name the acute rheumatic fever manifestation which is most likely to recur.
In a rural community, a patient presenting with chorea should have what essential cardiac investigation?
Echocardiogram to assess for acute rheumatic fever
Name 3 causes of a holosytolic murmur.
Name 3 causes of an early systolic murmur.

A pre systolic murmur or rumble of mitral stenosis precedes S1, a result of increased blood flow from atrial contraction. Following S2 (closure of the aortic and pulmonic valves) is the opening of the stenoic mitral valve (snap) and the low pitch mid diastolic murmur or rumble of mitral stenosis.

Describe the findings and identify the murmur.
[sound:aor2ricsconv.mp4]

S1 (mitral and tricuspid valve closure) is followed by a systolic ejection murmur due to the large stroke volume seen in aortic regurgitation. After S2 (aortic and pulmonic valve closure) there is a faint and short diastolic "bowing" murmur of aortic regurgitation.

Describe the findings and identify the murmur.
[sound:asc2ricsconv.mp4]

S1 (mitral and tricuspid valve closure) is followed by a mid systolic ejection murmur of aortic stenosis. A single S2 is from delayed aortic valve closure which occurs simultaneously with closure of the pulmonic valve.
Describe the characteristics of a murmur due to mitral stenosis.

Mid-diastolic murmur
Rumbling character
Starts with an opening snap
Tricuspid stenosis is best heard where?
What is Carvallo's sign or Rivero-Carvallo's sign?
Increase in the intensity of a murmur due to tricuspid stenosis with inspiration.
Describe the auscultation findings seen in tricuspid stenosis.

Mid-diastolic rumble
Best heard along the left sternal border
Increased intensity with inspiration (Carvallo's sign)
Mitral regurgitation is best heard with the patient in what position?
To where does the murmur of aortic regurgitation radiate?
What is the preferred antibiotic treatment of acute rheumatic fever?
Intramuscular benzathine penicillin G single dose
Describe the management of Sydenham chorea due to acute rheumatic fever.

Most causes do not require treatment and will resolve within several weeks to 6 months.
Can use carbamazepine and valproic acid.
Secondary prophylaxis of acute rheumatic fever is with what drug?
What type of infection with group A Streptococcus is most strongly associated with acute rheumatic fever?
What is the thought to be the underlying mechanism for carditis in acute rheumatic fever?
Structural similarity between some exogenous agent and human proteins, such that antibodies and T cells activated in response to the exogenous agent react with the human protein.
Common variable immunodeficiency is defined by what 3 characteristics?

Markedly reduced serum concentrations of immunoglobulin G (IgG), in combination with low levels of immunoglobulin A (IgA) and/or immunoglobulin M
Poor or absent response to immunisations
An absence of any other defined immunodeficiency state
Common variable immunodeficiency is most commonly diagnosed in what age group?

Defective B cell differentiation into plasma cells with impaired secretion of immunoglobulin.
Is the overall B cell number normal in patients with common variable immunodeficiency?
Yes, although many have reduced percentages of isotype-switched memory B cells (and lack plasma cells).
Memory B cells in humans can be identified on flow cytometry by the presence of what cluster of differentiation (CD)?
In patients wtih common variable immunodeficiency, there is impaired function of what 2 toll-like receptors on both B cells and dendritic cells?
B cell responses are initiabed by binding of viral RNA to what 2 toll-like receptors?
What is the name of the ligands to which toll-like receptors bind?
Toll-like receptors are part of the {{c1::innate}} immune system.
What was the clinical question studied in the RALES study?
In patients with HFrEF and NYHA class III-IV symptoms, does spironolactone reduce mortality?
What was the bottom line of the RALES study?
In patients with HFrEF (EF<35%) and NYHA III-IV symptoms, spironolactone led to a 30% reduction in all-cause mortality.

Describe 2 mechanisms (in addition to the diuretic and blood pressure lowering effects) of mineralocorticoid antagonist therapy which may contribue to reduced mortality in patients with heart failure with reduced ejection fraction.

Raising serum potassium
Blocking aldosterone effect on the heart

MRA therapy may offset the arrhythmogenic effects of hypokalaemia induced by non-potassium sparing diuretics.
MRA therapy reduces collagen synthesis and myocardial remodeling.
Atypical, rapid, and bizarre form of ventricular tachycardia that is characterised by a continuously changing axis of polymorphic QRS morphologies.
Give a definition for polymorphic ventricular tachycardia (torsades de pointes).
Ventricular rhythm faster than 100 beats per minute with frequent variations of the QRS axis, morphology or both.
What syndrome is associated with an increased risk of polymorphic ventricular tachcardia (torsades de pointes)?
The majority of drugs that produce acquired long QT syndrome act by blocking what current?
IKr current mediated by the potassium channel encoded by the KCNH2 gene
Name 3 electrolyte abnormalities which may predispose to torsades de pointes.
What is the cutoff for prolonged QTc in men and women?
What is the first-line therapy for patients with torsades de pointes?
Highly effective for both the treatment and prevention of recurrence of long QT-related ventricular ectopic veats or torsades de pointes.
Describe the management of a haemodynamically stable patient with torsades de pointes (4).

IV magnesium sulphate
Correction of metabolic/electrolyte derangements
Removal of inciting medications
Consider overdrive pacing in patients who are unresponsive to the above measures
Group 2 pulmonary hypertension is due to which underlying category of diseases?
Pulmonary hypertension due to left heart disease
Group 3 pulmonary hypertension is due to which underlying category of diseases?
Pulmonary hypertension due to chronic lung disease and/or hypoxaemia
Group 4 pulmonary hypertension is due to which underlying category of diseases?
Pulmonary hypertension due to chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension

Pulmonary hypertension due to unclear multifactorial mechanisms

Serum immunoglobulins

Exclusion of other causes of these abnormalities

Serum IgG should be low
Serum IgA and/or IgM should be low
One half of patient shave no detectable immunoglobulin.

Inflammatory bowel-like disease
Sprue-like illness with flat villi
Nodular lymphoid hyperplasia
Pernicious anaemia
Protein-losing enteropathy
Gastrointestinal lymphoma
Name 6 autoimmune disorders whcih are commonly associated with common variable immunodeficiency.

Autoimmune haemolytic anaemia (AIHA)
Immune thrombocytopenia (ITP)

IgG antibodies to tetanus and diphtheria (response to protein-based vaccines)

Patients with common variable immunodeficiency will have impaired responses to what 2 types of vaccinations?
Name 3 pulmonary manifestations of common variable immunodeficiency.

Restrictive lung dsiease (inflammatory disease from lymphocytic or granulomatous infiltrates)
Granulomatous disease (non-caseating)

Rheumatic mitral stenosis is a chronic condition and is not seen during the first episode of acute rheumatic carditis.

Usually cause elevated left atrial pressures

Severity of mitral stenosis
Cardiac output

Exaggerated immune response to specific bacterial epitopes in a susceptible host.
What is the natural history of mitral valve pathology following acute rheumatic fever?
Chronic rheumatic heart disease affecting the mitral valve progresses over years to decades, transitioning from mitral regurgitation to mitral stenosis.
Can pulmonary hypertension due to mitral stenosis be reversed?
Yes, mean pulmonary artery systolic pressure falls over several years
The rate of progression from asymptomatic to symptomatic phase in patients with mitral stenosis is largely dependent upon what factor?
Geographic areas: developed country vs developing country. Mitral stenosis progresses much more rapidly in developing countries, leading to symptoms in younger patients.
Prognosis of mitral stenosis dramatically worsens when what occurs?
Development of symptoms due to mitral stenosis.
What concomitant disease is the most common trigger of symptoms in patients with mitral stenosis?
Occurs in 45% of cases, making it the most common cause of disiability in a previously asymptomatic patient.

A woman with Graves' disease has had radioiodine ablation/thyroidectomy. Can her neonate develop neonatal Graves' hyperthyroidism?
Yes, thyrotropin receptor antibodies still persist despite thyroid ablation.
Axial spondyloarthritis (axSpa) can be classified into what 2 subtypes?
Ankylosing spondylitis exhibits sacroiliitis on x-ray. Nonradiographic axial spondyloarthritis active inflammation can only be seen on MRI or clinical signs/symptoms.

If the patient has received insulin therapy for > 2 weeks because this will generate insulin antibodies.

Reduced transcription of the gene (i.e. silencing) and decreased expression of the gene product frataxin.

Expanded trinucleotide (GAA) repeat in intron 1 of both alleles of the frataxin gene
What drug class must be stopped at least 36 hours before commencing sacubitril + valsartan?
Describe the mechanism of action of sacubitril with valsartan.

The active metabolite of sacubitril inhibits neprilysin reducing degradation of natriuretic peptides. It also increases angiotensin II concentration which is blocked by valsartan. The combination produces vasodilation, increases glomerular filtration rate, reduces sympathetic tone and aldosterone release, and increases bradykinin levels.
What was the clinical question studied in the CASTLE-AF study?

In patients with atrial fibrillation (AF) and symptomatic (NYHA II-IV) systolic heart failure (LVEF ≤ 35%), is catheter ablation superior to medical therapy (rate or rhythm control) with regard to death or hospitalization for heart failure?
What was the clinical question studied in the AFFIRM trial?
Among patients with atrial fibrillation and a high risk of stroke or death, what are the effects of rate control versus rhythm control on mortality?
What was the bottom line of the CASTLE-AF study?

In patients with AF and symptomatic (NYHA II-IV) systolic heart failure (LVEF ≤ 35%), catheter ablation is associated with a 16.1% absolute reduction in death or hospitalization for heart failure when compared to medical therapy (rate or rhythm control). This difference was driven both by a 11.6% absolute reduction in death and a 15.2% absolute reduction in hospitalization for heart failure. Catheter ablation was also associated with greater improvement in LVEF and long-term maintenance of sinus rhythm.

Antibodies to nuclear matrix protein (NPX)-2
Peak incidence of cancers associated with inflammatory myopathies usually occurs within what time period in relation to diagnosis?
Simultaneously with and during the first year after the diagnosis of muscle disease. Falls off gradually over the next 5 years of follow-up.

Sepsis originating from the result ulcer

Calcification, fibrointimal hyperplasia, and thrombosis in microvessels in the subcutaneous adipose tissue and dermis, often accompanied by necrosis of epidermal and adipose tissue, dermal–epidermal separation, panniculitis, proliferation of dermal endothelial cells, and extravascular calcifications.

Fish oil (equivalent to 2 - 4g of omega-3 fatty acids) orally, daily
PLUS
Fenofibrate
Statin therapy is not effective for severely elevated triglycerides, but may still reduce cardiovascular disease risk in these patients.
Statin therapy should not be combined with which fibrate?
Significantly increases the risk of myositis when given in combination with a statin - do not add gemfibrozil to statin therapy.
Which fibrate can be safely used in combination with statin therapy?
Name 2 proprotein convertase subtilisin/kexin type 9 (PCSK9) inhibitors.
Describe the mechanism of action of evolocumab.

Human monoclonal antibody that binds to proprotein convertase subtilisin/kexin type 9 (PCSK9). It inhibits PCSK9 degradation of LDL receptors which increases the number of LDL receptors thereby increasing hepatic LDL uptake and reducing serum LDL.
What was the clinical question studied in the FOURIER trial?

Among patients with clinical atherosclerotic disease and LDL > 1.8mmol/L despite high- or moderate-intensity statin therapy, does the addition of PCSK9 inhibitor evolocumab reduce major cardiovascular events compared to placebo?
Does evolocumab reduce cardiovascular death or total mortality?
In patients with clinical atherosclerotic disease and LDL > 1.8mmol/L despite statin therapy, the addition of evolucumab had what effect?
Reduction in non-fatal myocardial infarction, stroke, and revascularisation.
What is the effect of fish oil consumption on serum triglycerides?
What is the effect of fish oil on blood pressure?
Lowers systolic and diastolic blood pressure, including clinically menaingful reductions in those with hypertension, due to reductions in systemic vascular resistance.
What is the effect of fish oil on the risk of bleeding?

No clinically significant effect on bleeding risk.
Does not need to be stopped before surgery.
What was the clinical question studied in the ACCORD Lipid study?
Among adults with type 2 diabetes mellitus on statin monotherapy, does addition of a fibrate reduce risk of cardiovascular disease?
What was the bottom line of the ACCORD Lipid study?
Among adults with type 2 diabetes mellitus on statin monotherapy, the addition of fenofibrate does not reduce cardiovascular disease.
What advantage do drug-eluting coronary artery stents have over bare mental stents?
Drug-eluting stents (DES) reduce the rate of restenosis and, accordingly, target lesion revascularization compared to bare metal stents (BMS).
What is the mechanism by which drug-eluting coronary artery stents reduce the rate of restenosis when compared to bare metal stents?
The restenosis benefit of drug-eluting stents (DES) compared to bare metal stent (BMS) results from inhibition of in-stent neointimal hyperplasia.
The vast majority of bare metal stent occurs within what time period of insertion?
Thrombotic events with bare metal stents are uncommon after 30 days of treatment with dual antiplatelet therapy.
Name the single most important predictor of early and late coronary artery stent thrombosis.
Absence of platelet P2Y12 receptor blocker therapy
With regards to coronary artery stent thrombosis, which type of stent, bare metal or drug eluting, is superior?

Both randomized trial and observational study data have demonstrated that the cumulative rate of stent thrombosis is similar for bare metal and the first generation drug-eluting stents (SES and PES) at up to five years
What is the approximate incidence of coronary artery stent thrombosis in the first year following insertion?
Drops to approximately 0.2% per year thereafter
How does coronary artery stent thrombosis usually present?
Acute coronary syndrome, usually with ST elevation myocardial infarction (60%).
How is a diagnosis of coronary artery stent thrombosis usually made?
Describe the management of patients with ST elevation myocardial infarction due to coronary artery stent thrombosis.
Describe the difference between intracoronary stent restonsis and coronary stent thrombosis.

Coronary stent thrombosis is an abrupt thrombotic occlusion of a previously widelye patent stent.
Restenosis is a gradual re-narrowing of the stented segment that occurs mostly between 3 - 12 months after stent placement.
What advantage do drug-eluting coronary stents have over bare-metal stents?
Markedly reduce the incidence of intracoronary stent restenosis and target lesion revascularisation.
Intracoronary stent restenosis is primarily due to what pathologic process?
What is the formula for negative likelihood ratio?
Sensitivity is the probability that an individual with the disease will test positive. A test with high sensitivity will not miss many patients who have the disease (i.e. a low false negative rate).

Specificity is the probability that an individual without the disease will test negative. A test with high specificity will infrequently identify patients as having a disease when they do not (i.e. low flase positive results).
How is the sensitivity of a test calculated?
Number of patients with a positive test who have the disease (true positives) divided by all patients who have the disease.

Principal cells in the cortical collecting tubule
Acetazolamide acts in what part of the nephron?
Mannitol exerts its action on what part of the nephron?

What effect do loop diuretics have on renal calcium handling?
Describe the mechanism of action of loop diuretics.
Inhibition of the Na-K-2Cl carrier in the luminal membrane of the medullary and cortical thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle.
Describe the mechanism of action of acetazolamide.
Inhibits carbonic anhydrase resulting in loss of both NaCl (sodium chloride) and NaHCO3 (sodium bicarbonate).
